componenttext: Okay, so the first question related to the components of gross margin for the fourth quarter, as we mentioned I think in our comments, merchandise margin increased by about 195 basis points. Shrink was 25, freight was 20, occupancy levered by about 50, the DCs [distribution centers] levered by about 15. Those gains were partly offset by incentive costs in the quarter, along with investments we've made in the buying organization which totaled about 75 basis points.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On that point right there, John, is there something -- because the occupancy leverage point looked lower or you were getting more occupancy leverage for each comp point in the first half and less in the second half, so is there something we should be awar
componenttext: On that point right there, John, is there something -- because the occupancy leverage point looked lower or you were getting more occupancy leverage for each comp point in the first half and less in the second half, so is there something we should be aware of there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't believe so. There have been occasionally some reductions or some cash we received from reduced occupancy percentage and that does vary a bit by quarter. And we don't see that playing out much in 2010.
componenttext: No, I don't believe so. There have been occasionally some reductions or some cash we received from reduced occupancy percentage and that does vary a bit by quarter. And we don't see that playing out much in 2010.

componenttext: So the shrink, how that plays out for the year or so -- until we take our fiscal inventory, we're recurring at a rate, probably about 25 basis points less than we did last year. That all trues up in the third quarter depending on where that rate will come in, and then we'll go ahead and adjust the fourth quarter amount by whatever we think is appropriate. So for the first couple of quarters in 2010, we should expect about 25 basis points above that.

componenttext: And then just last thing, just in merchandise margin in Q2, how are you confident you can continue to drive that? Because it looks like it's tax impaired [ph] to me in Q2, just on the merchandise margin exclusive with shrink?

componenttextpreview: Yes. As we've said in our prepared comments, we do believe that the merchandise margins are sustainable. That's really driven by us, managing inventories tightly and in fact, in 2010, takes them down some more. So I believe that is sustainable.
componenttext: Yes. As we've said in our prepared comments, we do believe that the merchandise margins are sustainable. That's really driven by us, managing inventories tightly and in fact, in 2010, takes them down some more. So I believe that is sustainable.

componenttext: Well, we think there's some more. We haven't talked it out. We think there's a bit more. I can tell you we're taking inventories down, high-single digit this year. And again that, in '09, they were down kind of mid-double, so we're pretty confident about our ability to do that.

componenttext: Big picture question on expenses, just looking back to the 2004 time periods of today, sales are about 50% higher. The SG&A rates held constant, it may be even a little bit higher. And I'm just wondering if longer-term you see the SG&A rate improving as you continue to grow your store base and sales? And then maybe what's changing, and depending on your answer to that question, what would be changing over the next several years relative to the last several?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you go back to '04, which we don't want to do, things are a little different then. I think as we look at the expense ratios going forward, there are constant initiatives in the company dealing with labor efficiencies in the dd's and the stores, dealing
componenttext: If you go back to '04, which we don't want to do, things are a little different then. I think as we look at the expense ratios going forward, there are constant initiatives in the company dealing with labor efficiencies in the dd's and the stores, dealing with transportation optimization, import efficiency, we have initiatives around indirect procurement and we'll continue to make sure that the expense ratios are appropriate in the company. Having said that, we will also continue to invest in the merchandise organization, which we believe is obviously critical to what we're doing. Also in 2004, which I don't want to go back to, but we had no borrowings in '04. So there's a piece of incentive comp that's impacting the ratios currently.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, not even to focus so much on '04, it just seems like it's been a pretty steady rate over the past several years, and I guess I'm really wondering if there's a point over the next several where you see that rate coming down?
componenttext: John, not even to focus so much on '04, it just seems like it's been a pretty steady rate over the past several years, and I guess I'm really wondering if there's a point over the next several where you see that rate coming down?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when we get dd's more scale, that should help, and of historic numbers, that's kind [ph] of good. Also back then, I don't know if we had autumn [ph] expensing, so there's  a couple of other factors coming into that form.
componenttext: Yes, I think when we get dd's more scale, that should help, and of historic numbers, that's kind [ph] of good. Also back then, I don't know if we had autumn [ph] expensing, so there's  a couple of other factors coming into that form.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] from the merchandise margins but obviously impressed with the 195. Could you give us a sense, is it more driven by fewer markdowns, obviously with what you've been doing on inventory turn? And how you think about markup opportunity going f
componenttext: [indiscernible] from the merchandise margins but obviously impressed with the 195. Could you give us a sense, is it more driven by fewer markdowns, obviously with what you've been doing on inventory turn? And how you think about markup opportunity going forward?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That one, on the, to mark the result in merchant margin, it's disproportionately driven by markdowns. And relative to markups, if we look at 2010 and look at how we plan our AURs, we're flattish in AUR in 2010.
componenttext: That one, on the, to mark the result in merchant margin, it's disproportionately driven by markdowns. And relative to markups, if we look at 2010 and look at how we plan our AURs, we're flattish in AUR in 2010.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just following up on that, we have heard in the third quarter, ticket was down low-single, traffic was up low-double. Can you give us a sense in the fourth quarter what you saw on the ticket side? It sounds as if still traffic is a major driver b
componenttext: And then just following up on that, we have heard in the third quarter, ticket was down low-single, traffic was up low-double. Can you give us a sense in the fourth quarter what you saw on the ticket side? It sounds as if still traffic is a major driver but are you seeing any sort of improvement on the ticket?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in the fourth quarter, the trends continues. Transactions where low-double digits in the basket side. Basket was down low-single, so we a continuing trend, we saw in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: So in the fourth quarter, the trends continues. Transactions where low-double digits in the basket side. Basket was down low-single, so we a continuing trend, we saw in the fourth quarter.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly on dd's, in terms of obviously, a nice improvement in terms of mutual to earnings. In the guidance for 2010, could you give us a sense of what you're expecting the contribution from dd's?
componenttext: And then just lastly on dd's, in terms of obviously, a nice improvement in terms of mutual to earnings. In the guidance for 2010, could you give us a sense of what you're expecting the contribution from dd's?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a bit of flattish.
componenttext: It's a bit of flattish.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Jeff Klinefelter of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jeff Klinefelter of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: One for Michael, in terms of the competitive dynamic for 2010, and clearly you guys were stand out performer in '09. It was a very difficult and volatile market in terms of pricing. But what do you see in 2010? It's like, if there's going to be a risk out
componenttext: One for Michael, in terms of the competitive dynamic for 2010, and clearly you guys were stand out performer in '09. It was a very difficult and volatile market in terms of pricing. But what do you see in 2010? It's like, if there's going to be a risk out there to not overachieving, is it going back to an irrational pricing environment, are you seeing any inventory builds that concern you with other competitors? What's your view of the environment?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the environment from a promotional aspect, people have inventory are more under control. They continue to run tight inventories and that bodes well as a pricing comparisons for the off-site center.
componenttext: I think the environment from a promotional aspect, people have inventory are more under control. They continue to run tight inventories and that bodes well as a pricing comparisons for the off-site center.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So at this point, you don't see anything that concerns you on the competitive front?
componenttext: So at this point, you don't see anything that concerns you on the competitive front?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of just the inventory, great job in managing that, I know you guys have been continuing to drop but without any sort of negative impact on sales. Is this the micro merchandising system's leverage point? How far along on the continuum are you of r
componenttext: In terms of just the inventory, great job in managing that, I know you guys have been continuing to drop but without any sort of negative impact on sales. Is this the micro merchandising system's leverage point? How far along on the continuum are you of realizing the benefits of that system? Or is this just simply you're running the business more efficiently in terms of supply chain at this point?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a hard question to answer, Jeff. As you know, we've had micro merchandising up and running across the business since middle of 2009. We're very happy that it appears to be working well. But it's too early to tell what kind of an impact it's having on
componenttext: It's a hard question to answer, Jeff. As you know, we've had micro merchandising up and running across the business since middle of 2009. We're very happy that it appears to be working well. But it's too early to tell what kind of an impact it's having on the business. And frankly, there's so many other things that have gone on in the last six months in terms of the inventory cuts we've made, the sales performance we've had. But it's very hard to isolate the impact of micro merchandising. Our own internal view has always been, that it would take a while before we see the true benefits of micro merchandising. But It could be helping, it's just very hard for us to isolate that right now.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add, that the inventory we've been able to accomplish is, micro merchandising is helping, strengthening [ph] the efficiencies in our supply chain has helped us to be able to do this. And our view that we were carrying too much inventory and a
componenttext: I would just add, that the inventory we've been able to accomplish is, micro merchandising is helping, strengthening [ph] the efficiencies in our supply chain has helped us to be able to do this. And our view that we were carrying too much inventory and also our systems that we put in place in that year, we don't like to talk about in '04, has helped us isolate how we do carry those inventory.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Kimberly Greenberger of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Kimberly Greenberger of Citi.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could give us the longer-term view of entering new market. Historically, when you venture in new markets, what kind of sales productivity do you typically realize? Have you noticed that it's an operating margin in cancer or is there some
componenttext: I was hoping you could give us the longer-term view of entering new market. Historically, when you venture in new markets, what kind of sales productivity do you typically realize? Have you noticed that it's an operating margin in cancer or is there some pressure associated with the initial investment in the markets? If you could just reflect on historically how it's gone for you and help us understand how that might look in 2011, that would be great.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan. The answer is, that over the years, we've entered a lot of new markets. So there's been quite a variety of experience. In some markets we've entered where we've been pretty successful from the starting point [ph], and th
componenttext: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan. The answer is, that over the years, we've entered a lot of new markets. So there's been quite a variety of experience. In some markets we've entered where we've been pretty successful from the starting point [ph], and there are other markets who are taking a bit longer. The markets that we're looking at in 2011, first of all, they won't really have an impact in 2011 because it would be relatively few stores, few markets. And obviously, we're going to make sure we do as much preparation as possible to make sure that those are the kind of markets where we have as a little drag as possible in the first year or two. So it's a difficult question to answer because we've had some markets where we've been successful on the get go and some we're taking longer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: But, Michael, in the variety of experiences, have you had an opportunity to look at the new stores productivity, what would be like the best case scenario with that? 100% of the sales productivity? Or is that more like 80%? And then, just maybe just help
componenttext: But, Michael, in the variety of experiences, have you had an opportunity to look at the new stores productivity, what would be like the best case scenario with that? 100% of the sales productivity? Or is that more like 80%? And then, just maybe just help us bracket like the optimistic scenario versus the more conservative scenario, that would be really helpful.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can't put numbers on it. I would say, you have to assume that would be less than 100%. And certainly we would assume that to be less than 100%. What we're trying to focus on, Kimberly, is not so much the first year or two, it's more like three to f
componenttext: Yes. I can't put numbers on it. I would say, you have to assume that would be less than 100%. And certainly we would assume that to be less than 100%. What we're trying to focus on, Kimberly, is not so much the first year or two, it's more like three to five years out. What we're trying to get to at that point is a much stronger sales performance. I'm not trying to really put a bracket around it but certainly I think it will be [indiscernible]  If you expect that new stores and new markets in the first year or two are going to do as well as the existing markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Laura Champine of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Laura Champine of Cowen and Company.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is on SG&A expense, to keep it flat or maybe get a little bit of leverage, you'll need less dollar growth in the year, is that mostly as you lap the increase and incentive compensation in Q4? Or there are other ways that you plan to control SG
componenttext: My question is on SG&A expense, to keep it flat or maybe get a little bit of leverage, you'll need less dollar growth in the year, is that mostly as you lap the increase and incentive compensation in Q4? Or there are other ways that you plan to control SG&A expense a little tighter in 2010?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. There are some initiatives we have in place where particularly we could get some traction in SG&A. And you're absolutely correct relative to incentive costs, we do have higher incentive costs that will help us leverage G&A.
componenttext: Sure. There are some initiatives we have in place where particularly we could get some traction in SG&A. And you're absolutely correct relative to incentive costs, we do have higher incentive costs that will help us leverage G&A.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a little more color on what those initiatives are and as you try to help control SG&A expense in 2010?
componenttext: Could you give us a little more color on what those initiatives are and as you try to help control SG&A expense in 2010?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Those I've mentioned -- so we're constantly looking for labor efficiencies in the DCs and stores. There's initiatives around indirect procurement. There's initiatives around supply chain and efficiencies along the import line. There's work we're doing aro
componenttext: Those I've mentioned -- so we're constantly looking for labor efficiencies in the DCs and stores. There's initiatives around indirect procurement. There's initiatives around supply chain and efficiencies along the import line. There's work we're doing around transportations as well though, and a lot aspects to the business we keep working at the expense side of the business.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of David Mann of Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of David Mann of Johnson Rice.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you're in an inflection point now with dd's. And if I remember correctly, you were talking about getting to this break even level at a much higher number of stores. So can you talk a little bit now, as you go forward, as you're accelerating
componenttext: It sounds like you're in an inflection point now with dd's. And if I remember correctly, you were talking about getting to this break even level at a much higher number of stores. So can you talk a little bit now, as you go forward, as you're accelerating [indiscernible] how the store operating metrics of dd's compare to a Ross store, are the returns close to being comparable now?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I'll take that. As you say, over the last couple of years, we've kept dd's at around about 50 stores. And we've been doing some things to try and adjust an improved the performance of the business. And what we see, we like. We're very happy with ho
componenttext: David, I'll take that. As you say, over the last couple of years, we've kept dd's at around about 50 stores. And we've been doing some things to try and adjust an improved the performance of the business. And what we see, we like. We're very happy with how dd's has performed over the past 18 and 24 months. And that has caused us to expand the business as yet. And as Michael mentioned in his remarks, we'll be adding about 15 stores this year on the base of 50. And you can assume what 15 to grow the business over time. Obviously, underlying all that is quite a lot of financial analysis that we've done [indiscernible] that investors [ph] think that the returns are attractive. And there's so many aspects of the financial model but the difference are awesome [ph]. We took out those in the past. But net-net, in terms of overall return, a dd's store, actually throws off fairly similar returns to a Ross store. So we're pretty happy with dd's from that comparison.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then one other question, in terms of your attitude on Packaway, should we expect that Packaway percentages may change at all on sort of an annual basis as micro merchandising, as you continue to take down inventory per store?
componenttext: And then one other question, in terms of your attitude on Packaway, should we expect that Packaway percentages may change at all on sort of an annual basis as micro merchandising, as you continue to take down inventory per store?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the real driver of how Packaway will move or not will be the quality of what's out there, not based on micro merchandising.
componenttext: I think the real driver of how Packaway will move or not will be the quality of what's out there, not based on micro merchandising.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Patrick McKeever of MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Patrick McKeever of MKM Partners.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the 200 plus basis point increase in gross margin for the year, how much of that increase do you think was related to the overall weak microenvironment, the weak retail environment and department stores or other retailers, either shutting
componenttext: Just looking at the 200 plus basis point increase in gross margin for the year, how much of that increase do you think was related to the overall weak microenvironment, the weak retail environment and department stores or other retailers, either shutting down or pushing inventories back to the vendors? And I asked that because, I mean it's a common bearish [ph] out there right now that much of the gross margin improvement last year was environmental, so to speak. So I'm just wondering if you'd respond to that.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly try to break it apart. And I don't think we really know the answer, the impact of external factors, those things we get internally. The one thing we can anchor on, which I think is very important, is the inventory reductions we made. We can l
componenttext: We certainly try to break it apart. And I don't think we really know the answer, the impact of external factors, those things we get internally. The one thing we can anchor on, which I think is very important, is the inventory reductions we made. We can link those directly to long-term reductions. And we know that marked down reductions were the biggest single driver for gross margin improvement last year. So again, we look forward to 2010. That's why, as Michael and John made a comment about additional inventory reductions, we're trying to take [indiscernible] So we feel that a healthy sum [ph] of the improvement was driven by our actions that we took. And certainly, we were also helped by the economic environment.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my second question is on the buying organization. You made some comments that there were some incremental expenses, I'm just wondering if you could talk about some of the changes, or key additions, or just changes I guess that you've made in your
componenttext: And then my second question is on the buying organization. You made some comments that there were some incremental expenses, I'm just wondering if you could talk about some of the changes, or key additions, or just changes I guess that you've made in your buying organization over the past few quarters and how you think that might play out in 2010. I mean my understanding is that you've made some significant investments in new people and so forth, so I'm some just wondering if you could talk about that?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we did in late last year, we did promote several people. We've added more senior management in merchandising. We've also added more divisional merchandise managers and buyers. And actually, below buyers. So we've been building the organization in an
componenttext: Well, we did in late last year, we did promote several people. We've added more senior management in merchandising. We've also added more divisional merchandise managers and buyers. And actually, below buyers. So we've been building the organization in anticipation of our needs for greater market coverage in a competitive environment, in an environment that -- well in our business, we're essentially sold on vendor relationships. The more people we have covering the market, spending more time with resources, we think it's good thing for our business. So basically, what we've done is we've continue to split our businesses into tighter, into smaller and smaller segments, so people are responsible for a smaller pyramid, so they can focus more on the business, as well as bend the relationships. This additional splitting of the business helps us manage our inventory tighter, in addition to having greater market coverage. And we've also added more people in our planning area that matchup to the merchant headcount. So basically, we continue to split and split our businesses and then we continue to see it pay off from it.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman from Wells Fargo.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question about the Home category, correct me if I'm wrong but it seems like there's an acceleration over the past several months, your comps are around 20% or so. Can you talk about what you think is driving that, how much longer we can see that going for
componenttext: Question about the Home category, correct me if I'm wrong but it seems like there's an acceleration over the past several months, your comps are around 20% or so. Can you talk about what you think is driving that, how much longer we can see that going forward? And also, remind us what percent of your sales are in the Home category?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Home business is in the low-20% range of our mix, and the Home business has accelerated in the back half of last year and then continues into, certainly into February. And I would say that what's driving it, is we actually did add a lot of merchants t
componenttext: The Home business is in the low-20% range of our mix, and the Home business has accelerated in the back half of last year and then continues into, certainly into February. And I would say that what's driving it, is we actually did add a lot of merchants there. We did segment our businesses tighter. We also have from a competitor point of view, some retailers have exited the market and I think also environmentally, people are spending more time at home. Less time out, and they spend a little more on home products when that happens. So I think those are the reasons.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the regions, the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, just now that these outperformed, I believe they've been closing the gap towards the average for the chain and sort of the sales productivity. Can you talk how much they closed the gap, or maybe how much
componenttext: On the regions, the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, just now that these outperformed, I believe they've been closing the gap towards the average for the chain and sort of the sales productivity. Can you talk how much they closed the gap, or maybe how much below they are if they still are the corporate average?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're right, both Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast over the past 12 to 24 months have been performing very well. And we're very happy with how they've done. We are -- what I'd focus on more than sales part is actually their contribution. And actually from
componenttext: You're right, both Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast over the past 12 to 24 months have been performing very well. And we're very happy with how they've done. We are -- what I'd focus on more than sales part is actually their contribution. And actually from a contribution point of view, they're actually right in the pack [ph], in terms of contribution level. So that certainly is an improvement over the last years.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last year, I remember, you talked about tax refunds being higher and as a driver of your business at this time of last year, what have you seen this year for tax refunds I guess year-over-year?
componenttext: Last year, I remember, you talked about tax refunds being higher and as a driver of your business at this time of last year, what have you seen this year for tax refunds I guess year-over-year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'd looked at early refunds in terms of what drives our business. Clearly, there are some early refund activity this year, it's really very, very difficult to quantify at this time.
componenttext: We'd looked at early refunds in terms of what drives our business. Clearly, there are some early refund activity this year, it's really very, very difficult to quantify at this time.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Samuels of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Samuels of Oppenheimer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You guided on a great job, you have inventory turns over the last couple of years, and what I would just like to know is how often are you now shipping to the store? And with gas prices up rather significantly year-over-year, what sort of impact if any co
componenttext: You guided on a great job, you have inventory turns over the last couple of years, and what I would just like to know is how often are you now shipping to the store? And with gas prices up rather significantly year-over-year, what sort of impact if any could this potentially have not only for margin, but also for your customer?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the three, I think there were three questions kind of embedded in there, the frequency of delivery to stores, we deliver to stores everyday, every weekday. And that's part of our model, to make sure that we have spent [ph] much time in front o
componenttext: In terms of the three, I think there were three questions kind of embedded in there, the frequency of delivery to stores, we deliver to stores everyday, every weekday. And that's part of our model, to make sure that we have spent [ph] much time in front of the customer. Secondly, the impact of freight prices on our own business in terms of tracking cost, certainly there's some price expense and we built that into our budget and our guidance for the year, assuming that the fuel prices go up this year, we do some assumptions [indiscernible]. And then thirdly, I think the question was about, the impact of fuel prices on our customers, which is very hard for us to read. There are so many things affecting our customers. So it is very hard for us to know how high fuel prices will impact them, whether it will drive them more to a first [ph] or cause them to shop less [indiscernible].

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk a little bit about, Richard, and I never want to go back to 2004 by the way, ever, ever, ever. Richard, you mentioned, was it Michael, one of you guys talked a little bit about the new markets for dd's and Ross, and I think you mention
componenttext: Could you just talk a little bit about, Richard, and I never want to go back to 2004 by the way, ever, ever, ever. Richard, you mentioned, was it Michael, one of you guys talked a little bit about the new markets for dd's and Ross, and I think you mentioned there weren't new markets but if you could just remind us if there are new markets or more recent markets that you're opening in this year? And when you think about the dd's, could you just talk a little bit about the ideal adjacencies and kind of centers that you're opening in? I know you're still seeing opportunities in those centers the way you saw several years ago?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just repeat the I first part?
componenttext: Could you just repeat the I first part?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you mentioned that you weren't opening in any new markets this year, but I was curious if you're opening in any, what I would still call newer markets, that if you have a few stores but aren't really mature for the two brands. And then just again
componenttext: I think you mentioned that you weren't opening in any new markets this year, but I was curious if you're opening in any, what I would still call newer markets, that if you have a few stores but aren't really mature for the two brands. And then just again about the adjacency for dd's and if you're still seeing the same kinds of deals?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the new markets we're entering, so for dd's this year, we will be entering a couple of new markets. For Ross this year, we'll just be in existing markets. But I think as we announced previously, our intent for 2011, is to begin to enter additional new
componenttext: On the new markets we're entering, so for dd's this year, we will be entering a couple of new markets. For Ross this year, we'll just be in existing markets. But I think as we announced previously, our intent for 2011, is to begin to enter additional new markets for Ross in that year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: As it relates to dd's adjacencies, we continue to look for more urban locations for dd's. Those locations tend to be in older centers that require us to do some work on it. But we found that the identities appropriate for the dd's business model. And we c
componenttext: As it relates to dd's adjacencies, we continue to look for more urban locations for dd's. Those locations tend to be in older centers that require us to do some work on it. But we found that the identities appropriate for the dd's business model. And we continue to see those opportunities in the markets that we're operating in and the new markets that we're going to go into

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a demographic that's ideal for dd's or has it become a little bit more broad-based?
componenttext: Is there a demographic that's ideal for dd's or has it become a little bit more broad-based?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is. Actually that's one of the things that we did a lot of research on a couple of years ago. As I understand it, the ideal demographics of dd's. And we do have same profile that will lay down demographics. That's what we're executing against.
componenttext: Yes, there is. Actually that's one of the things that we did a lot of research on a couple of years ago. As I understand it, the ideal demographics of dd's. And we do have same profile that will lay down demographics. That's what we're executing against.

componenttext: Dana, I'll take CapEx. So this year, we're planning around $250 million. The breakdown is about $80 million in new stores. We're investing a bit more on new stores as we had to take the ownership for the constructions, the build-out of the stores, as the credit markets have frozen a lot for new commercial development. We're going to invest about $65 million in existing stores which include some touch up work, some refresh, some maintenance work. Our DC's about $40 million. And about $30 million in G&A and other IT areas.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores' Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2009 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session.
componenttext: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores' Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2009 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Balmuth.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Joining me on our call today are: Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice President and Chief F
componenttext: Good morning. Joining me on our call today are: Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director, Investor Relations. We will begin today with a review of our fourth quarter and 2009 performance, followed by our outlook for 2010 and the longer term. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have.Before we start, I want to note that our comments on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results and other matters that are based on management's current forecast of aspects of the company's future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. These risk factors are detailed in today's press release and our fiscal 2008 Form 10-K, fiscal 2009 Form 10-Qs and fiscal 2009 and 2010 Form 8-Ks on file with the SEC.Earnings per share for the 13 weeks ended January 30, 2010, grew 53% to $1.16, up from $0.76 for the 13 weeks ended January 31, 2009. Net earnings for the quarter grew to a record $142.9 million, up 47% from $97.4 million in the prior-year period. For the 52 weeks ended January 30, 2010, earnings per share grew 52% to $3.54, up from $2.33 for the 52 weeks ended January 31, 2009. Net earnings for fiscal 2009 increased 45% to a record $442.8 million, up from $305.4 million in 2008. Fourth quarter sales increased 14% to $1,980,000,000, with comparable store sales up 10% over the prior year. For the full year, total sales rose 11% to $7,184,000,000, with same-store sales up 6% on top of a 2% gain in the prior year. Our better-than-expected sales for both the quarter and the year benefited from healthy traffic to our stores, as an increasing number of shoppers were attracted to our great values. The best-performing merchandise categories for both the quarter and the year were Shoes, Dresses and Home, all posting double-digit gains in same-store sales for both periods. Geographic trends were broad-based with high-single to low-double-digit percentage same-store sales increases across all regions for the quarter and mid- to high-single-digit gains for the year.The Northwest and Southwest regions were the best performing markets in the fourth quarter, while the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast were the top regions for the year. California same-store sales rose 8% during the fourth quarter and 6% for the full year.We are extremely pleased with our outstanding sales and earnings results. Our 52% gain in earnings per share in fiscal 2009 was on top of a 23% increase in the prior year. Ross was one of the very few retailers to generate this level of robust growth in 2009. Our ability to execute a rough [ph] (25:18) price strategy successfully throughout all areas of our company was the primary driver of our exceptional financial results. During one of the most challenging economic and retail environments, we not only generated much higher-than-planned revenues, but did so with record merchandise gross margins that drove double-digit operating profit as a percent of sales.Earnings before interest and taxes for 2009 fourth quarter grew about 260 basis points to 11.7% of sales, up from 9.1% in the prior year. This higher profit margin was mainly due to a 230 basis point reduction in cost of goods sold, along with a 30 basis points decline in selling, general and administrative costs. For the 2009 fiscal year, operating margin increased about 250 basis points over the prior year to 10.1% of sales, also driven by a 230 basis point decline in cost of goods sold, combined with a 20 basis point reduction in selling, general and administrative expenses. Key drivers of our improved profitability for both the fourth quarter and the year were significant growth in merchandise gross margin, lower shortage costs and leverage on operating expenses from the strong gains in same-store sales. John will provide some additional color on operating margin trends in a few minutes.On average, in-store inventories were down in the mid-teen percentage range throughout 2009 and ended the year down about 11%. Now operating our business with much lower in-store inventories increases the percentage of fresh and exciting merchandise that our customers see when they shop at our stores. By exceeding our sales targets with leaner inventories, we realized significantly fast returns in 2009, which resulted in much fewer markdowns. For 2010, we are planning further reductions of in-store inventories with average levels targeted down in the mid- to high-single digit percentage range compared to 2009. We believe our ongoing focus on tight inventory management will further accelerate inventory turns and maximize merchandise gross margin.Turning to our store expansion program, we added 56 new stores in 2009, including 52 Ross Dress for Less and four dd's DISCOUNTS locations. dd's DISCOUNTS' outstanding performance in 2009 continued in the fourth quarter, with sales and profitability for both the quarter and the full year well ahead of our original expectations. In fact, the earnings impact or drag from dd's was relatively neutral in 2009 compared to a 35 basis point drag in 2008. We are pleased to report that on a pretax basis before interest cost and corporate overhead allocations, dd's DISCOUNTS was profitable for the first time in its history.This improvement was driven by both higher sales productivity and much higher gross margin. Like Ross, dd's is benefiting from our ability to deliver a faster flow of fresh and exciting products to our stores while operating on lower inventory levels. dd's strong gains in sales and profitability also reflect that its valued focus merchandise offerings are resonating well with its customers. dd's results make us even more enthusiastic about dd's long-term prospects and our plans to accelerate its expansion in 2010 and beyond.Now let's talk about our financial condition. Our balance sheet remains very healthy with cash and short-term investments of $770 million at year end. Our higher cash balances benefited primarily from much better-than-expected earnings, as well as reduced working capital needs from operating our stores with lower inventories. Our consistently strong cash flows enabled us to continue to enhance stockholder return through both our dividend and stock repurchase programs. During 2009, after internally financing both our working capital and capital expenditure requirements, we used available cash to buy back $70 million of common stock in the fourth quarter and $300 million for the fiscal year. This allowed us to retire about 1.6 million and 7.4 million shares in the fourth quarter and fiscal year periods, respectively. This completed the prior two-year $600 million program announced in early 2008.In January 2010, our Board of Directors approved a new two-year $750 million stock repurchase program, along with a 45% increase in our quarterly cash dividend to $0.16 per common share. These actions reflect our confidence and our ongoing ability to generate healthy amount of excess cash and our long-term commitment to enhancing stockholder returns.Now I'd like to review the 2010 targets we communicated with our January sales release in early February. We have a resilient and flexible off-price model that when we execute it well, enables us to deliver solid results in both favorable and challenging business cycles. That said, we are off against a year of exceptional growth in both sales and earnings in 2009. As a result, we have been prudent in setting our targets for 2010 with the hope that we can do better, as we recently did in February when sales were well above plans. For the 2010 fiscal year, we are forecasting same-store sales to increase 1% to 2% on top of a strong 6% gain in 2009, and projecting earnings per share to increase 7% to 12%, to $3.80 to $3.95. It's important to remember that this projected earnings per share growth is on top of an outstanding 52% increase in 2009, our largest annual increase in more than a decade. We are projecting the largest earnings per share increases in the first half of 2010. We faced the easiest prior-year sales and operating margin comparisons in the first quarter, providing us greater opportunity for improvement during this period. For the second quarter, earnings per share are forecast to grow in the low-double digit percentage range. We are up against to our toughest sales in merchandise margin and shortage comparisons in the third and fourth quarters of 2010. In the second half of 2009, a 9% increase in comparable store sales and operating profits that grew over 300 basis points as a percent of sales drove a 67% increase in earnings per share. As a result, we are projecting flattish earnings per share in the second half versus the prior year. Now John will provide some additional details on our fourth quarter results, and review the underlying operating statement assumptions that support our earnings per share targets for the first quarter and fiscal 2010.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. As Michael discussed, our fourth quarter operating margin increased by 260 basis points over the prior year due to a 230 basis point reduction in cost of goods sold and a 30 basis point decline in selling, general and administrative co
componenttext: Thank you, Michael. As Michael discussed, our fourth quarter operating margin increased by 260 basis points over the prior year due to a 230 basis point reduction in cost of goods sold and a 30 basis point decline in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sale. The higher gross margin during the fourth quarter was driven mainly by a better merchandise margin, which increased about 195 basis points. Lower shortage and freight added about 25 and 20 basis points, respectively to better margins. The remaining operating margin gains came from the leverage of occupancy, distribution, store and corporate expenses from the roll of up to [ph] 10% increase in same-store sales, partially offset by higher incentive costs compared to the prior year.Now I'll spend a few moments summarizing the underlying assumptions that support our 2010 fiscal year EPS targets. A more detailed version is available in the written transcript of our January sales release recorded comments in the Investors section of our corporate website. Our fiscal year 2010 earnings per share forecast of $3.80 to $3.95 is based on projected total sales growth of 4% to 5% over the prior year, driven by a 4% to 5% increase in the number of stores and a 1% to 2% increase in same-store sales on top of the 6% gain in 2009. Our projected store growth includes about 35 Ross Dress for Less and as Michael mentioned, 15 new dd's DISCOUNTS locations. The accelerated growth for dd's includes our anticipated entry into a few new states in the latter part of the year. We are forecasting operating margin of 10.1% to 10.3%, which represents flat incremental growth over 2009 when EBIT grew by about 250 basis points. Drivers include flattish merchandise gross margin in 2010 with flat to incremental improvement in expenses.Net interest expense is expected to be about $8 million to $9 million. Our tax rate is planned to be approximately 38% to 39%, and we expect an approximate 4% decline in diluted shares to about $120 million. Our first quarter guidance that we issued at the beginning of February was for same-store sales to increase 2% to 3% on top of a 3% increase last year, and earnings per share to be in the range of $0.92 to $0.95, up from $0.72 in the first quarter of 2009. As Michael noted, these targets reflected that we face our ages [ph] prior-year sales and operating margin comparisons in the first quarter. We recently reported February sales that were well ahead of our expectations, with same-store sales up 11% versus our forecast for a 4% of 5% increase. While we are encouraged by the healthy start to the year, February is a small month of the quarter for both sales and earnings with the important March-April Easter selling period still ahead of us. In addition, Easter is moving to the first Sunday of fiscal April 2010 from the second Sunday in fiscal April last year, shifting all of our pre-Easter business into March. Holiday shifts like this are always very difficult to predict. As a result, earlier this month, we reiterated our guidance for same-store sales to be up 3% to 4% in March and flat to up 1% in April. Now I'll turn the call back to Michael for some closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. We continue to believe that the main reason for our exceptional performance in 2009 has been our ability to execute our strategies with unwavering focus and discipline throughout all areas of the company. This has enabled us to capitalize
componenttext: Thank you, John. We continue to believe that the main reason for our exceptional performance in 2009 has been our ability to execute our strategies with unwavering focus and discipline throughout all areas of the company. This has enabled us to capitalize on our favorable position as a value retailer in the current economic and retail environment. By consistently stocking our stores with great bargains, operating our business on lower inventories to drive faster turns and fewer markdowns and strictly controlling expenses throughout the business, we have been able to deliver record sales and earnings results. Looking ahead, we believe that consumers increased focus on value will continue for the foreseeable future, which bodes well for our bargain-oriented merchandise strategy. We know that our ability to give our customers the best value as possible on a wide array of name brand fashions for the family and the home is, and always will be, the key to our success. To ensure that we have plenty of access to enough quality name brand products to grow profitably in the future, we continue to make further investments in our merchandise organizations.  We currently have hundreds of merchants, sourcing products everyday from thousands of vendors. As previously mentioned, another key driver of our record results in 2009 was the significant gains we realized in merchandise gross margin. This improved profitability was not only from buying great product, but also from maintaining strict controls on merchandise inventories. We also believe there are additional opportunities to enhance revenues and gross margin over the longer term through micro-merchandising, which was rolled out to all merchandise categories across all Ross locations in 2009. These tools consist of new systems and processes to help us more accurately plan, buy and allocate merchandise down to a local level. Building inventory plans from the bottom up, ahead of each season and then trending sales and inventory levels against these plans as the season progresses, is expected to strengthen our ability overtime, to get the right merchandise to the right store at the right time. Today, we operate a total of 1,000 Ross and dd's locations in just 27 states, giving us significant room to grow going forward. As we have previously noted, our planned unit growth of 4% to 5% for Ross and dd's, combined in 2010, is projected to accelerate to about 7% in 2011, when we expect to enter new geographic markets for both chains. There remains plenty of expansion opportunity as we believe that Ross can have as many as 1,500 locations, and that dd's DISCOUNTS can ultimately grow to approximately 500 stores. That would represent a doubling of our existing store base and exciting prospects. Finally, while our 2009 operating margin is close to record levels, we believe that this current level of profitability is not only sustainable, but have some room for incremental improvement in 2010 as noted in our guidance. While our projected earnings per share range for 2010 reflect a slightly lower growth rate than we would normally forecast, we felt that this was appropriate based on the very strong 52% earnings per share gain we are up against from 2009. Again, our practice is to be somewhat cautious in our planning process while constantly striving to beat our targets as we have done over the past couple of years. Over the longer term, we believe that earnings per share growth of 10% to 15% is a realistic and very achievable goal. The formula remains unchanged: A combination of store growth, comparable store sales gains, flat to incremental improvement in operating margin, generating excess cash that can be used to fund our dividend and stock repurchase programs. In closing, I want to reiterate that we have a long history of delivering solid sales and earnings gains, with very healthy cash flow and returns on equity and assets in all types of economic environments. We are confident that we can continue to do so in 2010 and beyond. At this point, we'd like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010

componenttextpreview: Okay, so the first question related to the components of gross margin for the fourth quarter, as we mentioned I think in our comments, merchandise margin increased by about 195 basis points. Shrink was 25, freight was 20, occupancy levered by about 50, th
componenttext: Okay, so the first question related to the components of gross margin for the fourth quarter, as we mentioned I think in our comments, merchandise margin increased by about 195 basis points. Shrink was 25, freight was 20, occupancy levered by about 50, the DCs [distribution centers] levered by about 15. Those gains were partly offset by incentive costs in the quarter, along with investments we've made in the buying organization which totaled about 75 basis points.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On that point right there, John, is there something -- because the occupancy leverage point looked lower or you were getting more occupancy leverage for each comp point in the first half and less in the second half, so is there something we should be awar
componenttext: On that point right there, John, is there something -- because the occupancy leverage point looked lower or you were getting more occupancy leverage for each comp point in the first half and less in the second half, so is there something we should be aware of there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't believe so. There have been occasionally some reductions or some cash we received from reduced occupancy percentage and that does vary a bit by quarter. And we don't see that playing out much in 2010.
componenttext: No, I don't believe so. There have been occasionally some reductions or some cash we received from reduced occupancy percentage and that does vary a bit by quarter. And we don't see that playing out much in 2010.

componenttextpreview: So the shrink, how that plays out for the year or so -- until we take our fiscal inventory, we're recurring at a rate, probably about 25 basis points less than we did last year. That all trues up in the third quarter depending on where that rate will come
componenttext: So the shrink, how that plays out for the year or so -- until we take our fiscal inventory, we're recurring at a rate, probably about 25 basis points less than we did last year. That all trues up in the third quarter depending on where that rate will come in, and then we'll go ahead and adjust the fourth quarter amount by whatever we think is appropriate. So for the first couple of quarters in 2010, we should expect about 25 basis points above that.

componenttext: And then so in Q3 though, when you're up against the big number you got in Q3 '09, you would expect that to be flat or down?

componenttext: Actually, assuming we got the accrual right, actually it will be up against that of the 100-basis-points-or-so benefit received in the fourth quarter so it will actually be down.

componenttext: And then just last thing, just in merchandise margin in Q2, how are you confident you can continue to drive that? I mean, the inventory -- I heard what you said about inventory not too awesome, so is that what it is? Because it looks like it's tax impaired [ph] to me in Q2, just on the merchandise margin exclusive with shrink?

componenttextpreview: Yes. As we've said in our prepared comments, we do believe that the merchandise margins are sustainable. That's really driven by us, managing inventories tightly and in fact, in 2010, takes them down some more. So I believe that is sustainable.
componenttext: Yes. As we've said in our prepared comments, we do believe that the merchandise margins are sustainable. That's really driven by us, managing inventories tightly and in fact, in 2010, takes them down some more. So I believe that is sustainable.

componenttext: Well, we think there's some more. We haven't talked it out. We think there's a bit more. I can tell you we're taking inventories down, high-single digit this year. And again that, in '09, they were down kind of mid-double, so we're pretty confident about our ability to do that.
