componenttext: And just a final tack on, on the dd's stores, I mean do you see any differences there on the inventory benefit you've had at Ross? Is there an angle on that side?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've taken a similar approach with dd's. In 2009, we reduced the inventory levels of dd's throughout and saw quite some benefits. So we're very happy with how dd's has been performing, both in terms of the top line and in terms of market.
componenttext: We've taken a similar approach with dd's. In 2009, we reduced the inventory levels of dd's throughout and saw quite some benefits. So we're very happy with how dd's has been performing, both in terms of the top line and in terms of market.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Tunick of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Tunick of JPMorgan.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the first question, relative to what we think dd's will do in 2010, we're obviously pleased with the results this year. We see dd's breaking even to being slightly profitable in 2010. On the gains in dd's, actually, [indiscernible] very, very good soli
componenttext: So the first question, relative to what we think dd's will do in 2010, we're obviously pleased with the results this year. We see dd's breaking even to being slightly profitable in 2010. On the gains in dd's, actually, [indiscernible] very, very good solid margin improvements and some leverage [indiscernible].

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we've looked at the quarter, looked at the year, obviously, we came out of the box very strong in February. Our policy is really not to comment mid-month on sales trends, and so we'll just leave it there right now. And clearly, we want to get through t
componenttext: As we've looked at the quarter, looked at the year, obviously, we came out of the box very strong in February. Our policy is really not to comment mid-month on sales trends, and so we'll just leave it there right now. And clearly, we want to get through the month and take a look at Easter and then revisit it when they come.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Lejuez of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Lejuez of Credit Suisse.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Big picture question on expenses, just looking back to the 2004 time periods of today, sales are about 50% higher. The SG&A rates held constant, it maybe even a little bit higher. And I'm just wondering if longer-term, you see the SG&A rate improving as y
componenttext: Big picture question on expenses, just looking back to the 2004 time periods of today, sales are about 50% higher. The SG&A rates held constant, it maybe even a little bit higher. And I'm just wondering if longer-term, you see the SG&A rate improving as you continue to grow your store base and sales? And maybe what's changing -- and depending on your answer to that question, what would be changing over the next several years, relative to the last several?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can comment on that, Paul. Yes, if you go back to '04, which we don't want to do, things are a little different then. I think as we look at the expense ratio, going forward, there are constant initiatives in the company dealing with labor efficiencies i
componenttext: I can comment on that, Paul. Yes, if you go back to '04, which we don't want to do, things are a little different then. I think as we look at the expense ratio, going forward, there are constant initiatives in the company dealing with labor efficiencies in the DCs and the stores, dealing with the transportation optimization, import efficiency, we have initiatives around indirect procurement and we'll continue to make sure that the expense ratios are appropriate in the company. Having said that, we will also continue to invest in the merchandise organization, which we believe is obviously, critical to what we're doing. Also in 2004, which I don't want to go back to, but we had no borrowings in '04. So there's a piece of incentive comp that's impacting the ratios currently.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, not even to focus so much on '04, just it seems like it's been a pretty steady rate over the past several years, and I guess I'm really wondering if there's a point over the next several where you see that rate coming down?
componenttext: John, not even to focus so much on '04, just it seems like it's been a pretty steady rate over the past several years, and I guess I'm really wondering if there's a point over the next several where you see that rate coming down?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when we get dd's more scaled, that should help, and of historic numbers, that kind of good. Also back then, I don't know if we had [indiscernible] expensing. So there's a couple of other factors coming into that form.
componenttext: Yes, I think when we get dd's more scaled, that should help, and of historic numbers, that kind of good. Also back then, I don't know if we had [indiscernible] expensing. So there's a couple of other factors coming into that form.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not to harp on the merchandise margins, but obviously, impressed with the 195. Could you give us a sense, is it more driven by fewer markdowns, obviously with what you've been doing on inventory turn? And how do you think about markup opportunity, going f
componenttext: Not to harp on the merchandise margins, but obviously, impressed with the 195. Could you give us a sense, is it more driven by fewer markdowns, obviously with what you've been doing on inventory turn? And how do you think about markup opportunity, going forward?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That one on -- the result in merchant margin, it's disproportionately driven by markdowns. And relative to markups, if we look at 2010 and look at how we plan our AURs, we're flattish in AURs in 2010.
componenttext: That one on -- the result in merchant margin, it's disproportionately driven by markdowns. And relative to markups, if we look at 2010 and look at how we plan our AURs, we're flattish in AURs in 2010.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just following up on that, we have heard in the third quarter, ticket was down low-singles, traffic was up low-doubles. Could you give us a sense in the fourth quarter, what you saw on the ticket side? It sounds as if still traffic is a major dri
componenttext: And then just following up on that, we have heard in the third quarter, ticket was down low-singles, traffic was up low-doubles. Could you give us a sense in the fourth quarter, what you saw on the ticket side? It sounds as if still traffic is a major driver, but are you seeing any sort of improvement on the ticket?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in the fourth quarter, the trends continued. Transactions where low-double digits and the basket size -- basket was down low-single, so we saw a continuing trend we saw in the third quarter.
componenttext: So in the fourth quarter, the trends continued. Transactions where low-double digits and the basket size -- basket was down low-single, so we saw a continuing trend we saw in the third quarter.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly on dd's, in terms of obviously, a nice improvement in terms of neutral to earnings. In the guidance of 2010, could you give us a sense of what you're expecting the contribution from dd's?
componenttext: And then just lastly on dd's, in terms of obviously, a nice improvement in terms of neutral to earnings. In the guidance of 2010, could you give us a sense of what you're expecting the contribution from dd's?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's basically flattish.
componenttext: It's basically flattish.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Jeff Klinefelter of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jeff Klinefelter of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: One for Michael, in terms of the competitive dynamic for 2010. I mean, clearly, you guys were a stand out outperformer in '09. And it was a very difficult and volatile market in terms of pricing. But what do you see in 2010? It's like, if there's going to
componenttext: One for Michael, in terms of the competitive dynamic for 2010. I mean, clearly, you guys were a stand out outperformer in '09. And it was a very difficult and volatile market in terms of pricing. But what do you see in 2010? It's like, if there's going to be a risk out there to not overachieving, is it even going back to an irrational pricing environment? Are you seeing any inventory builds that concern you with other competitors? What's your view of the environment?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the environment, from a promotional aspect, people have inventory more under control. They continue to run tight inventories and that bodes well as a pricing comparisons for the off-site center.
componenttext: I think the environment, from a promotional aspect, people have inventory more under control. They continue to run tight inventories and that bodes well as a pricing comparisons for the off-site center.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So at this point, you don't see anything that concerns you on the competitive front?
componenttext: So at this point, you don't see anything that concerns you on the competitive front?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of just the inventory, again, great job in managing that, I know you guys have been continuing to drop, but without any sort of negative impact on sales. Is this the micro merchandising system's leverage point? How far along, on the continuum, ar
componenttext: In terms of just the inventory, again, great job in managing that, I know you guys have been continuing to drop, but without any sort of negative impact on sales. Is this the micro merchandising system's leverage point? How far along, on the continuum, are you of realizing the benefits of that system? Or is this just simply just running the business more efficiently in terms of supply chain at this point?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a hard question to answer, Jeff. As you know, we've had micro merchandising up and running across the business since middle of 2009. We're very happy that it appears to be working well. But it's too early to tell what kind of an impact it's having on
componenttext: It's a hard question to answer, Jeff. As you know, we've had micro merchandising up and running across the business since middle of 2009. We're very happy that it appears to be working well. But it's too early to tell what kind of an impact it's having on the business. And frankly, there's so many other things that have gone on in the last six months in terms of the inventory cuts we've made, the sales performance we've had. But it's very hard to isolate the impact of micro merchandising. Our own internal view has always been, that it would take a while before we see the true benefits of micro merchandising. But It could be helping, it's just very hard for us to isolate that right now.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add, that the inventory -- we've been able to accomplish it. Micro merchandising is helping, straighten with the efficiencies in our supply chain has helped us to be able to do this. And our view that we were carrying too much inventory and a
componenttext: I would just add, that the inventory -- we've been able to accomplish it. Micro merchandising is helping, straighten with the efficiencies in our supply chain has helped us to be able to do this. And our view that we were carrying too much inventory and also our systems that we put in place in that year, we don't like to talk about in '04, has helped us isolate how we do carry those inventory.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Kimberly Greenberger of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Kimberly Greenberger of Citi.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could give us the longer-term view of entering new market. Historically, when you venture in new markets, what kind of sales productivity do you typically realize? Have you noticed that it's an operating margin in cancer or is there some
componenttext: I was hoping you could give us the longer-term view of entering new market. Historically, when you venture in new markets, what kind of sales productivity do you typically realize? Have you noticed that it's an operating margin in cancer or is there some pressure associated with the initial investment in the markets? If you could just reflect on historically how it's gone for you and help us understand how that might look in 2011, that would be great.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan. The answer is, that over the years, we've entered a lot of new markets. So there's been quite a variety of experience. In some markets we've entered where we've been pretty successful from the starting point [ph], and th
componenttext: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan. The answer is, that over the years, we've entered a lot of new markets. So there's been quite a variety of experience. In some markets we've entered where we've been pretty successful from the starting point [ph], and there are other markets who are taking a bit longer. The markets that we're looking at in 2011, first of all, they won't really have an impact in 2011 because it would be relatively few stores, few markets. And obviously, we're going to make sure we do as much preparation as possible to make sure that those are the kind of markets where we have as a little drag as possible in the first year or two. So it's a difficult question to answer because we've had some markets where we've been successful on the get go and some we're taking longer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: But, Michael, in the variety of experiences, have you had an opportunity to look at the new stores productivity, what would be like the best case scenario with that? 100% of the sales productivity? Or is that more like 80%? And then, just maybe just help
componenttext: But, Michael, in the variety of experiences, have you had an opportunity to look at the new stores productivity, what would be like the best case scenario with that? 100% of the sales productivity? Or is that more like 80%? And then, just maybe just help us bracket like the optimistic scenario versus the more conservative scenario, that would be really helpful.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can't put numbers on it. I would say, you have to assume that would be less than 100%. And certainly we would assume that to be less than 100%. What we're trying to focus on, Kimberly, is not so much the first year or two, it's more like three to f
componenttext: Yes. I can't put numbers on it. I would say, you have to assume that would be less than 100%. And certainly we would assume that to be less than 100%. What we're trying to focus on, Kimberly, is not so much the first year or two, it's more like three to five years out. What we're trying to get to at that point is a much stronger sales performance. I'm not trying to really put a bracket around it but certainly I think it will be [indiscernible]  If you expect that new stores and new markets in the first year or two are going to do as well as the existing markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Laura Champine of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Laura Champine of Cowen and Company.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is on SG&A expense, to keep it flat or maybe get a little bit of leverage, you'll need less dollar growth in the year, is that mostly as you lap the increase and incentive compensation in Q4? Or there are other ways that you plan to control SG
componenttext: My question is on SG&A expense, to keep it flat or maybe get a little bit of leverage, you'll need less dollar growth in the year, is that mostly as you lap the increase and incentive compensation in Q4? Or there are other ways that you plan to control SG&A expense a little tighter in 2010?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. There are some initiatives we have in place where particularly we could get some traction in SG&A. And you're absolutely correct relative to incentive costs, we do have higher incentive costs that will help us leverage G&A.
componenttext: Sure. There are some initiatives we have in place where particularly we could get some traction in SG&A. And you're absolutely correct relative to incentive costs, we do have higher incentive costs that will help us leverage G&A.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a little more color on what those initiatives are and as you try to help control SG&A expense in 2010?
componenttext: Could you give us a little more color on what those initiatives are and as you try to help control SG&A expense in 2010?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Those I've mentioned -- so we're constantly looking for labor efficiencies in the DCs and stores. There's initiatives around indirect procurement. There's initiatives around supply chain and efficiencies along the import line. There's work we're doing aro
componenttext: Those I've mentioned -- so we're constantly looking for labor efficiencies in the DCs and stores. There's initiatives around indirect procurement. There's initiatives around supply chain and efficiencies along the import line. There's work we're doing around transportations as well though, and a lot aspects to the business we keep working at the expense side of the business.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of David Mann of Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of David Mann of Johnson Rice.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you're at an inflection point now with dd's. And if I remember correctly, you were talking about getting to this break even level at a much higher number of stores. So can you talk a little bit now, as you go forward, as you're accelerating
componenttext: It sounds like you're at an inflection point now with dd's. And if I remember correctly, you were talking about getting to this break even level at a much higher number of stores. So can you talk a little bit now, as you go forward, as you're accelerating strength out there, how the store operating metrics of dd's compare to a Ross Store? Are the returns close to being comparable now?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I'll take that. As you say, over the last couple of years, we've kept dd's at around about 50 stores. And we've been doing some things to try and adjust an improve the performance of the business. And what we see, we like. We're very happy with how
componenttext: David, I'll take that. As you say, over the last couple of years, we've kept dd's at around about 50 stores. And we've been doing some things to try and adjust an improve the performance of the business. And what we see, we like. We're very happy with how dd's has performed over the past 18 to 24 months. And that's what's caused us to expand the business as yet. And as Michael mentioned in his remarks, we'll be adding about 15 stores this year on the base of 50. And you can assume, we'll continue to grow the business over time. Obviously, underlying all that is quite a lot of financial analysis that we've done on the business that investors think that the returns are attractive. And there's so many aspects of the financial model but the difference revolves in we took out those in the past. But net-net, in terms of overall return, our dd store, as you might see, actually throws off a very similar returns to a Ross Store. So we're pretty happy with dd's from that comparison so...

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of your attitude on packaway, should we expect that the packaway percentages may change at all on, sort of an annual basis as micro merchandising and as you continue to take down inventory per store?
componenttext: In terms of your attitude on packaway, should we expect that the packaway percentages may change at all on, sort of an annual basis as micro merchandising and as you continue to take down inventory per store?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the real driver of how packaway will move or not will be the quality of what's out there, not based on micro merchandising.
componenttext: I think the real driver of how packaway will move or not will be the quality of what's out there, not based on micro merchandising.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Patrick McKeever of MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Patrick McKeever of MKM Partners.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the 200 plus basis point increase in gross margin for the year, how much of that increase do you think was related to the overall weak microenvironment, the weak retail environment and department stores or other retailers, either shutting
componenttext: Just looking at the 200 plus basis point increase in gross margin for the year, how much of that increase do you think was related to the overall weak microenvironment, the weak retail environment and department stores or other retailers, either shutting down or pushing inventories back to the vendors? And I asked that because, I mean it's a common bearish argument out there right now that much of the gross margin improvement last year was environmental, so to speak. So I'm just wondering if you'd respond to that.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly try to break it apart. And I don't think we really know the answer, the impact of external factors, those things are things that we did internally. The one thing that we can anchor on, which I think is very important, is the inventory reducti
componenttext: We certainly try to break it apart. And I don't think we really know the answer, the impact of external factors, those things are things that we did internally. The one thing that we can anchor on, which I think is very important, is the inventory reductions we made. We can link those directly to long-term reductions. And we know that markdown reductions were the biggest single driver of gross margin improvement last year. So as we look forward to 2010, that's why, as Michael and John made their comments about additional inventory reductions we're planning to take next year. So we feel that this will take a healthy chunk of the improvement was driven by our actions that we took. And then certainly, we were also helped by the economic [ph] environment.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my second question is on the buying organization. You made some comments that there were some incremental expenses there. I'm just wondering if you could talk about some of the changes, or key additions, or just changes, I guess, that you've made
componenttext: And then my second question is on the buying organization. You made some comments that there were some incremental expenses there. I'm just wondering if you could talk about some of the changes, or key additions, or just changes, I guess, that you've made in your buying organization over the past few quarters and how you think that might play out in 2010. I mean, my understanding is that you've made some significant investments in new people and so forth. So I was just wondering if you could talk about that?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we did in late last year, we did promote several people. We've added more senior management in merchandising. We've also added more divisional merchandise managers and buyers. And actually, in below buyers. So we've been building the organization in
componenttext: Well, we did in late last year, we did promote several people. We've added more senior management in merchandising. We've also added more divisional merchandise managers and buyers. And actually, in below buyers. So we've been building the organization in anticipation of our needs for greater market coverage in a competitive environment, in an environment that -- well in our business, that were essentially built on vendor relationships. The more people we have covering the market, spending more time with resources, we think it's a good thing for our business. So basically, what we've done is we've continue to split our businesses into tighter, into smaller and smaller segments, so people are responsible for smaller pyramids, so they can focus more on the business, as well as vendor relationships. This additional splitting of the business helps us manage our inventory tighter, in addition to having greater market coverage. And we've also added more people in our planning area that matchup to the merchant headcount. So basically, we continue to split and split our businesses and then we continue to see it pay off from it.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman from Wells Fargo.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question about the Home category, correct me if I'm wrong, but it seems like there's an acceleration over the past several months, your comps are around 20% or so. Can you talk about what you think is driving that? How much longer we can see that going fo
componenttext: Question about the Home category, correct me if I'm wrong, but it seems like there's an acceleration over the past several months, your comps are around 20% or so. Can you talk about what you think is driving that? How much longer we can see that going forward? And also, remind us what percent of your sales are in the Home category?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Home business is in the low-20% range of our mix, and the Home business has accelerated in the back half of last year and then continues into, certainly into February. And I would say that what's driving it, is we actually did add a lot of merchants t
componenttext: The Home business is in the low-20% range of our mix, and the Home business has accelerated in the back half of last year and then continues into, certainly into February. And I would say that what's driving it, is we actually did add a lot of merchants there. We did segment our businesses tighter. We also have, from a competitive point of view, some retailers have exited the market and I think also environmentally, people are spending more time at home and less time out, and they spend a little more on home products when that happens. So I think those are the reasons.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the regions, the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, I guess now that these outperformed, I believe they've been closing the gap towards the average for the chain in terms of sales productivity. Can you talk how much they've closed the gap? Or maybe how mu
componenttext: On the regions, the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, I guess now that these outperformed, I believe they've been closing the gap towards the average for the chain in terms of sales productivity. Can you talk how much they've closed the gap? Or maybe how much below they are, if they still are the corporate average?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're right, both Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, over the past 12 to 24 months, have been performing very well. And we're very happy with how they've done. What I'd focus on more than sales part of it is actually their contribution. And actually from a
componenttext: You're right, both Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, over the past 12 to 24 months, have been performing very well. And we're very happy with how they've done. What I'd focus on more than sales part of it is actually their contribution. And actually from a contribution point of view, they're actually right in the path in terms of the contribution level. And that, certainly, is an improvement over the last years.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last year, I remember, you've talked about tax refunds being higher and as a driver of your business at this time of last year, what have you seen this year for tax refunds, I guess, year-over-year?
componenttext: Last year, I remember, you've talked about tax refunds being higher and as a driver of your business at this time of last year, what have you seen this year for tax refunds, I guess, year-over-year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because we looked at early refunds in terms of what drives our business, clearly, there are some early refund activity this year. It's really very, very difficult to quantify at this point.
componenttext: Because we looked at early refunds in terms of what drives our business, clearly, there are some early refund activity this year. It's really very, very difficult to quantify at this point.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Samuels of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Samuels of Oppenheimer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've guys have done a great job, you have inventory turns over the last couple of years, and what I would just like to know is how often are you now shipping to the stores? And with gas prices up rather significantly year-over-year, what sort of impact,
componenttext: You've guys have done a great job, you have inventory turns over the last couple of years, and what I would just like to know is how often are you now shipping to the stores? And with gas prices up rather significantly year-over-year, what sort of impact, if any, could this potentially have not only on margins, but also for your customer?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of -- there are three, I think there were three questions kind of embedded in there, the frequency of delivery to stores, we deliver to stores everyday, barring weekends. So every weekday. I think that's part of our model to make sure that we hav
componenttext: In terms of -- there are three, I think there were three questions kind of embedded in there, the frequency of delivery to stores, we deliver to stores everyday, barring weekends. So every weekday. I think that's part of our model to make sure that we have that much spent time in front of the customer. Secondly, the impacts of freight prices on our own business, in terms of trucking costs, certainly there's some price expense and we built that into our budget and our guidance for the year, assuming that fuel prices go up this year, we do some assumptions. And then thirdly, I think the question was about, the impact of fuel prices on our customers, which is very hard for us to read. There's so many things affecting our customers. So it is very hard for us to know about how high fuel prices will impact them, whether it will drive them more to a price or cause them to shop less so [indiscernible].

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010

I know you're still seeing the opportunities in those centers the way you saw several years ago? I think you mentioned that you weren't opening in any new markets this year, but I was curious if you're opening in any, what I would still call, newer markets, that you have a few stores but aren't really mature for the two brands. And then just, again, about the adjacencies for dd's and if you're still seeing the same kinds of deals?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2010

componenttext: I'll take the first one and then Gary can respond on the second. On the new markets we're entering, so for dd's this year, we will be entering a couple of new markets. For Ross this year, we'll just be in existing markets. But I think as we announced previously, our intent in 2011, is to begin to enter additional new markets for Ross in that year.

And we continue to see those opportunities in the markets that we're operating in and the new markets that we're going to go into.

componenttext: Dana, I'll take CapEx. So this year, we're planning around $250 million. The breakdown is about $80 million in new stores. We're to invest about $65 million in existing stores, which include some touch up work, some refresh, some maintenance work. DC is about $40 million. And about $30 million in G&A and other IT areas.

componenttext: And then Dana, your question on what's next, after Michael [indiscernible] I guess there a couple of things. headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores First Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared remarks by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Ins
componenttext: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores First Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared remarks by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Balmuth. You may now begin.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on the call are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice Pr
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on the call are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director of Investor Relations. 
We'll begin with a brief review of our first quarter performance, followed by our outlook for the second quarter. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. Before we begin, I want to note that our comments on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results and other matters that are based on management's current forecast of aspects of the company's future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. These risk factors are detailed in today's press release, in our fiscal 2009 Form 10-K and 2010 Form 8-Ks on file with the SEC.
Turning to our results. Today, we reported first quarter earnings per share of $1.16, up from $0.72 per share for the 2009 first quarter. These results represent an outstanding 61% increase on top of 20% growth in the prior year. Net earnings for the current quarter, the current-year quarter, grew 56% to a record $142.3 million, up from $91.4 million in the prior-year period. Our 2010 first quarter sales increased 14% to $1,935,000,000, with comparable store sales up 10% on top of a 3% gain in the prior year.
We are very pleased with our exceptional first quarter performance, which was driven by robust sales gains and record levels of profitability that were well ahead of plan. We believe our results continue to benefit from the superior execution of our off-price strategies combined with our favorable position as a value retailer in the current economic and retail environment.
During the first quarter, we continued to see healthy traffic to our stores as an increasing number of shoppers were attracted to our wide assortments of fresh and exciting name-brand bargains. Shoes and Home were the top performing merchandise categories, both with same-store sales gains in the high teen percentage range, while the Northwest and Florida were the strongest regions, posting low to mid teen increases in comparable store sales. California, which was impacted by unseasonable weather in April, posted a solid same-store sales gain of 7% for the quarter on top of a 4% increase in the prior year. 
Operating margin grew about 320 basis points to a record 12.1% due to a 230 basis point increase in gross margin and a 90 basis point improvement in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales. Key drivers of our improved profitability in the first quarter were significant growth in merchandise gross margin and leverage on operating expenses from the double-digit gain in same-store sales. John will provide some additional details on operating margin trends in a few minutes. 
As we ended the first quarter, total consolidated inventories were down 1% with average selling store inventories down about 8%. Packaway was about 33% of total inventories compared to 34% at this time last year. For 2010, we continue to plan further reductions of in-store inventories with average levels targeted down in the mid to high single-digit percentage range compared to 2009. Our customers continue to respond favorably to the higher percentage of fresh and exciting merchandise, resulting from our faster inventory turns. Additionally, our ongoing focus on tight inventory management also helps to maximize merchandise gross margins.
Turning to our store expansion program. We remain on track with our 2010 opening program, adding 14 net new Ross and two dd's DISCOUNTS in the first quarter. We are also pleased to report that dd's DISCOUNTS' strong performance in 2009 continued in the first quarter. Our accelerated growth plans for this promising business remain on track with a total of 15 new locations planned for 2010.
Based on our first quarter results and outlook for the balance of the year, we continue to expect dd's DISCOUNTS to be slightly profitable in 2010 before allocations for corporate expense. Like Ross, dd's is benefiting from our ability to deliver a faster flow of fresh and exciting product to our stores by operating on lower inventory levels. The continued solid gains in sales and profitability at dd's also reflect that its value-focused merchandise offerings are resonating well with its customers, and we are very excited about our accelerated expansion plans for dd's in 2010 and beyond.
Now let's talk about our financial condition. We are pleased to report that both our balance sheet and cash flows remain healthy. We ended the quarter with $826 million of cash and short-term investments. Our cash position benefited from our much-better-than-expected earnings and reduced working capital needs as we operate the business on lower inventories. 
We also returned a significant amount of our excess cash to stockholders through our dividend and stock repurchase programs. Earlier this year, we raised our cash dividend by 45% and announced a new two-year $750 million stock repurchase program for 2010 and 2011. During the first quarter, we repurchased 1.8 million shares of common stock for an aggregate purchase price of $94 million and remain on track to complete approximately $375 million of our current authorization by the end of 2010. 
Now John will provide some additional color on our first quarter results and details on our guidance for the second quarter.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As Michael noted, we saw healthy traffic to our stores during the first quarter. Our 10% comparable store sale gain was driven by high single-digit growth in a number of transactions, combined with a low single-digit increase in the size of the
componenttext:
Thank you. As Michael noted, we saw healthy traffic to our stores during the first quarter. Our 10% comparable store sale gain was driven by high single-digit growth in a number of transactions, combined with a low single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. 
Again, operating margin improved by about 320 basis points in the quarter to 12.1%, driven by a 230 basis point increase in gross margin and a 90 basis point decline in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales. 
Merchandise margin increased about 130 basis points, including our shortage accrual that was about 25 basis points lower than the prior year. We also realized leverage on occupancy and distribution expenses of about 70 and 40 basis points, respectively. Partially offsetting these improvements was a 10 basis point increase in freight cost. 
The decline in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales was due to a combination of leverage on both store and corporate expenses from the robust 10% increase in same-store sales. Our buyback program drove a 3% reduction in diluted shares outstanding.
Let's turn now to our second quarter guidance. As noted in today's press release, our previously issued guidance for the second quarter remains unchanged. While we are exceedingly pleased with our excellent start to the year, sales trends in the current macroeconomic and retail climate can be difficult to predict. In addition, on a two-year basis, we are anniversarying tougher comparisons in the second quarter when same-store sales rose 9% for 2008 and 2009 combined, after being up 6% for the first quarter. 
We believe that planning somewhat cautiously while hoping to do better is appropriate in this environment. This practice has enabled us to chase the business, resulting in faster inventory turns and better gross margin and expense leverage when we do outperform.
As a result, for the second quarter, we continue to forecast the comparable store sales gains of 3% to 4% and earnings per share of $0.95 to $0.99. This represents forecasted EPS growth of 16% to 21% on top of an outstanding 52% gain in the second quarter of 2009. These targets are based on the following assumptions: Total sales are expected to grow about 7% to 8%, driven by a combination of new store growth and, as mentioned, same-store sales that are up 3% to 4%. We are forecasting about 15 net new stores to open during the period, including 12 Ross Dress for Less and three dd's DISCOUNTS. We are planning comparable store sales gains of 2% to 3% for May and 3% to 4% for both June and July. Last year, same-store sales rose 4%, 1% and 4%, in May, June and July, respectively.
Operating margin for the second quarter is expected to be 10.2% to 10.4%, up from 9.7% last year. This represents a projected 50 to 70 basis point increase on top of a 260 basis point gain in the second quarter of 2009. Net interest expense is planned to be approximately $2.5 million, and our tax rate is expected to be about 39%. We also estimate weighted average diluted shares outstanding of about $121 million. 
As noted in today's press release, fiscal 2010 EPS is projected to grow 16% to 20% to $4.11 to $4.24, up from $3.54 last year. This forecasted increase is especially noteworthy considering it is also on top of a robust 52% gain in EPS in 2009. Now I'll turn the call back to Michael.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. I want to reiterate how pleased we are by our excellent start to the year. Again, while we plan strong earnings growth in the first quarter, our actual results were even better than expected. As mentioned earlier, through strong execution
componenttext:
Thank you, John. I want to reiterate how pleased we are by our excellent start to the year. Again, while we plan strong earnings growth in the first quarter, our actual results were even better than expected. As mentioned earlier, through strong execution of our off-price strategies, we have been able to take advantage of our favorable position as a value retailer in the current economic and retail environment.
Looking ahead, we believe that consumers focus on value will continue for the foreseeable future, which bodes well for our bargain-oriented business. We also know that our ability to give our customers the best values possible on a wide array of name-brand fashions for the family and the home is and always will be the key to our success. We remain committed to ensuring that we have access to as wide a supply of bargains as possible by making ongoing investments in our merchandise organization. 
A larger number of merchants increases the contact we have with our resources and maximizes our potential to be in the right place at the right time to take advantage of the best value-priced branded products in the marketplace. To maximize our prospects for future sales and earnings growth, we will continue our efforts to stock our stores with great bargains, operate our business on lower inventories and strictly control expenses throughout the company. 
At this point, we'd like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

componenttextpreview: Just a question on costs as we go through the year. Lot of chatter right now from the vendors all the way back in the supply chain to the retailers about some pricing pressure from various factors, raw materials, labor, transportation, et cetera. In terms
componenttext: Just a question on costs as we go through the year. Lot of chatter right now from the vendors all the way back in the supply chain to the retailers about some pricing pressure from various factors, raw materials, labor, transportation, et cetera. In terms of the dynamics with both your pre-season and in-season purchasing as an off-price retailer, can you just talk a little bit about kind of what you're seeing or hearing so far and how you expect it to play out over the next couple of seasons?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We hear the same chatter that you're describing and we haven't seen any material change yet. A couple of pockets where there've been slight changes, but for us, our business is a value business based on a differential between our sales in department store
componenttext: We hear the same chatter that you're describing and we haven't seen any material change yet. A couple of pockets where there've been slight changes, but for us, our business is a value business based on a differential between our sales in department stores and other mainstream retailers. So however this plays out, if we do our job effectively and execute our off-price purchasing model correctly, then we'll be able to keep the value differential we need from department stores and provide our customers bargains. And that's what we're focusing on.

componenttext: I'll take that, Kimberly. I mean -- typically, when we enter new market, our store productivity starts out a little bit slower than existing markets. Within five years or so, within three to five years, we expect those productivity levels to come up closer to the average.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, are there any strategies that you could employ as you're entering these new markets that would help boost the productivity in those newer stores? Is it a matter of getting to a critical mass of stores so that you can effectively market in that ne
componenttext: Michael, are there any strategies that you could employ as you're entering these new markets that would help boost the productivity in those newer stores? Is it a matter of getting to a critical mass of stores so that you can effectively market in that new geography? Or what are the key drivers of that lower productivity that you might be able to proactively attack on the front end?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer to question is, yes, there are. And from the experience we've had of entering new markets, we've identified a number of things that we plan to use and prepare for as we enter new markets in 2011. It includes pretty much all the things you just
componenttext: The answer to question is, yes, there are. And from the experience we've had of entering new markets, we've identified a number of things that we plan to use and prepare for as we enter new markets in 2011. It includes pretty much all the things you just described, trying to boost our awareness earlier, trying to make sure that the assortment match the particular need for the customers in those markets, try to get to critical mass sooner. So it really is all of those things that you'd expect.

componenttext: So we're going to have this big shrink true-up coming, I guess, right, in comparison-, I guess, wise, in the third quarter. So I just -- some color on how you're thinking as we compare against the shrink true-up in the third quarter. And then maybe for Michael, you're obviously increasingly excited about dd's. And maybe if you could just share with us either where productivity is today versus sort of maybe where you think you can get to, the four-wall opportunity at dd's versus Ross. Just maybe some more metrics around the dd's business?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, on the shrink true-up we had last year, it benefited third quarter by about 110 basis points. As we plan this year, we accrued at that historic level. Clearly, if we do better than we've done historically, we should be able to pick some up in the th
componenttext: Sure, on the shrink true-up we had last year, it benefited third quarter by about 110 basis points. As we plan this year, we accrued at that historic level. Clearly, if we do better than we've done historically, we should be able to pick some up in the third quarter. But having said that, we're not planning on that at this point in time.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Brian, on your second question. Yes, we're very excited about how dd is performing. In the first quarter, it continued to perform well ahead of plan. So we're very excited about that performance. You asked about operating metrics versus Ross. I think
componenttext: And Brian, on your second question. Yes, we're very excited about how dd is performing. In the first quarter, it continued to perform well ahead of plan. So we're very excited about that performance. You asked about operating metrics versus Ross. I think we've said in the past that gross margins are higher at dd's, but operating expenses are also higher. So in terms of contribution margin, four-wall contribution is very comparable to Ross. Now obviously, when you run that all the way down to operating margin, because it's a smaller business that isn't yet really of scale, it doesn't have the same operating margin as Ross. But once we get up to scale, we have a critical mass of stores, we expect the economics to be very comparable and very attractive.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the inventory turn philosophy in the speed to market, I mean you'll continue to run with down inventory per foot in the back half. Maybe just talk about some of the processes or things that have changed in the organization over the last year or tw
componenttext: Just on the inventory turn philosophy in the speed to market, I mean you'll continue to run with down inventory per foot in the back half. Maybe just talk about some of the processes or things that have changed in the organization over the last year or two?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think your main question there was whether we'll continue to run at low inventory levels, the answer is yes, we will. And that will be supported by, as you say, by our supply chain being faster than -- by the improvements we've made in terms of supply c
componenttext: I think your main question there was whether we'll continue to run at low inventory levels, the answer is yes, we will. And that will be supported by, as you say, by our supply chain being faster than -- by the improvements we've made in terms of supply chain speed.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to the SG&A performance. We saw sort of a similar comp in the fourth quarter and yet you were able to leverage expenses a lot better. Could you kind of help us understand how that happened? Are we still at that 3% break-even comp or ar
componenttext: My question relates to the SG&A performance. We saw sort of a similar comp in the fourth quarter and yet you were able to leverage expenses a lot better. Could you kind of help us understand how that happened? Are we still at that 3% break-even comp or are you now able to leverage on a -- are you doing better or is that breakeven, even lower?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the first part of that question, there's always timing differences between quarters. So some of that came into play between the fourth quarter and the first quarter. We have been able to lower the break-even point. We used to be slightly above 3%
componenttext: Sure. On the first part of that question, there's always timing differences between quarters. So some of that came into play between the fourth quarter and the first quarter. We have been able to lower the break-even point. We used to be slightly above 3%, now we're probably between a 2% and a 3% on the break-even point relative to G&A.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're going to have to walk us through that one? What are the changes, where -- how have you been able to do that? What areas and how sustainable is that?
componenttext: You're going to have to walk us through that one? What are the changes, where -- how have you been able to do that? What areas and how sustainable is that?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're constantly looking for areas to take that comp in the business. We have done work in productivity in the distribution centers. We can work in productivity at a store level. We have also been very active in the indirect procurement areas as we
componenttext: Sure. We're constantly looking for areas to take that comp in the business. We have done work in productivity in the distribution centers. We can work in productivity at a store level. We have also been very active in the indirect procurement areas as we source those things we need, non-merchandise-type items we need in our business. So those programs have been pretty successful for us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: I wanted to ask in April where there was an impact on your business in California. And we've been hearing from some other retailers about pressure in May so far, especially in some of the Northern states. Can you talk a little bit about weather impacting your business in May? I know you're more in the Southern markets. So in your markets, are you seeing any impact on kind of what is your May guidance assume for weather for the month?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: Evren, yes, we do think weather had an impact in April. And then on May, we actually don't comment late month in terms of May trends.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could ask another question. On the categories, Shoes have been very strong for you. Can you talk a little bit about what's driving that? Are you allocating more space? Are you buying from different vendors? And kind of thoughts on maybe using some of
componenttext: If I could ask another question. On the categories, Shoes have been very strong for you. Can you talk a little bit about what's driving that? Are you allocating more space? Are you buying from different vendors? And kind of thoughts on maybe using some of those strategies in the other categories?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've allocated a little more inventory to it. We're turning it extremely fast. And there's some key driving trends there. And also we've strengthened our merchant organization in Shoes.
componenttext: We've allocated a little more inventory to it. We're turning it extremely fast. And there's some key driving trends there. And also we've strengthened our merchant organization in Shoes.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak from SP Research.

componenttext: Just circling back one more time on April and I'm aware of the weather. But in California, I mean, do you think the whole -- because I think you did a negative two, right, in April. Do you think the whole issue there was weather? Did you see anything different, southern versus northern? Did you see anything different in sort of non-weather-related categories in California that month which give you confidence? And then on your guidance, just given what happened with the Memorial Day shift, what are you contemplating there for the July 4 shift? Do you expect there to be an impact? And then the last question is just on ticket. The slight increase you've seen in AUR, is that mix? What's driving that? And are you seeing that in those businesses? It's just kind of what are you seeing from the consumer in response to price?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Stacy, I'll take the first part of that. In terms of April in California, I would say there was nothing unique about California in April. The same drivers that we mentioned in the early remarks around weather and the timing of Easter I think applies in Ca
componenttext: Stacy, I'll take the first part of that. In terms of April in California, I would say there was nothing unique about California in April. The same drivers that we mentioned in the early remarks around weather and the timing of Easter I think applies in California. I'll let John comment on the July 4 shift. And let me just answer your third question before you get off [ph] (32:54). On ticket, the one point I'd make about ticket is, the slight increase that we've seen in ticket this year should be set against the fact that we saw a decline in ticket last year. So I would just put that in that context. You want to talk on July?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the calendar shift in the second quarter, Memorial Day is -- the fact that it's actually in June, slightly beneficial to us in May. Less -- when I say slightly, very slightly, probably less than a point impact in May. And the 4th of July shift
componenttext: Sure. So on the calendar shift in the second quarter, Memorial Day is -- the fact that it's actually in June, slightly beneficial to us in May. Less -- when I say slightly, very slightly, probably less than a point impact in May. And the 4th of July shift, its move is pretty minimal as well. So although those two holidays are moving around, not as big impact in any one specific month to us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: And I would just add, as a non-promotional retailer, it has less of an effect.

componenttext: That was Easter, the Easter shift. We may have misjudged the Easter shift on how much business moved from month to month, between March and April.

componenttext: It can move around. It's probably a mix of both, more inclined to say mix.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the sales, retail does seem like we've hit a little air pocket here. And John, can you give us some clarity on product availability? And is it consistent right now with what you would characterize as a move out of past recession or do you think you're
componenttext: On the sales, retail does seem like we've hit a little air pocket here. And John, can you give us some clarity on product availability? And is it consistent right now with what you would characterize as a move out of past recession or do you think you're seeing a good healthy level of product availability given some weakness that we've seen elsewhere? And second, what is the confidence level on the average basket improvement and whether we've successfully passed the baton in that direction versus traffic?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Product availability, I would say, availability has been pretty good. Actually, I'd say very good. And as retailers have hit a bit of a bump, it's gotten better. And that's -- we kind of expect the year to have decent availability. There was a sense of op
componenttext: Product availability, I would say, availability has been pretty good. Actually, I'd say very good. And as retailers have hit a bit of a bump, it's gotten better. And that's -- we kind of expect the year to have decent availability. There was a sense of optimism in both the manufacturers and retailers about the year, and that usually leads to more products being produced by manufacturers and also to some cancellations as we had some bumps in the road. Our department store has hit bumps in the road. So we feel pretty good about what we've been seeing in products and pretty good about the future of product availability for this year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, as it relates to your question regarding the traffic versus ticket versus AUR and your comment whether we've passed the baton or not, we're not sure about that. It's pretty uncertain out there still. The economy is tough to judge. What we're concern
componenttext: Jeff, as it relates to your question regarding the traffic versus ticket versus AUR and your comment whether we've passed the baton or not, we're not sure about that. It's pretty uncertain out there still. The economy is tough to judge. What we're concerned with is making sure that we maintain that value differential with the bargain for the stores.

componenttext: First question on dd's. What number of stores do you think you need to hit in order to achieve scale such that your EBIT margin is in line with that of Ross Stores?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle, I'll answer that with -- I'll give you two answers, all right. First of all, in terms of -- it has actually a positive profitability. I think we've mentioned dd's is already at positive profitability, just to clarify that. In terms of seeing the
componenttext: Michelle, I'll answer that with -- I'll give you two answers, all right. First of all, in terms of -- it has actually a positive profitability. I think we've mentioned dd's is already at positive profitability, just to clarify that. In terms of seeing the same EBIT margin as Ross, frankly, that's tough because Ross is a thousand-store business. So I think as we do our financial projections, it's a few hundred stores before dd's hits the same EBIT margin as Ross, but that's a pretty high hurdle.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of your full year EPS guidance, does that assume any further share repurchase activity beyond the first quarter? And then this is a follow-up to that. If you take the midpoint of your full year EPS guidance for this year, it implies seco
componenttext: And then in terms of your full year EPS guidance, does that assume any further share repurchase activity beyond the first quarter? And then this is a follow-up to that. If you take the midpoint of your full year EPS guidance for this year, it implies second half EPS is roughly flat year-over-year. So what's driving that conservative outlook?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Michelle, on the first question, the board approved in January a $750 million share repurchase program. We plan to execute half of that this year. I think we've spent $95 million during the first quarter, so we have a ways to go. Our view is we'd sp
componenttext: Sure. Michelle, on the first question, the board approved in January a $750 million share repurchase program. We plan to execute half of that this year. I think we've spent $95 million during the first quarter, so we have a ways to go. Our view is we'd spend about $375 million for the year, pretty straight, lined up over the period. You're correct on the second question, in your assumption that we are projecting fairly flat comps in the second half and fairly flat earnings growth. That's based on a 9% comp increase in the back half last year and terrific earnings per share performance. So we're up against some pretty tough numbers.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: Yes, it is.

componenttext: When you look out preliminarily to next year, do you think inventory per store can continue to decline?

componenttextpreview: Yes, it might. It'll probably decline at a lower rate than we've been at, but I would expect it to still decline. Remember, we have a -- we put systems inclusive of micro merchandising and that helped us get better productivity out of our inventory by sto
componenttext: Yes, it might. It'll probably decline at a lower rate than we've been at, but I would expect it to still decline. Remember, we have a -- we put systems inclusive of micro merchandising and that helped us get better productivity out of our inventory by store, by class, by store.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Which is a good segue, I was curious if you could give us a little more update on where you are with micro merchandising and whether you think you're getting some benefit there this past quarter?
componenttext: Which is a good segue, I was curious if you could give us a little more update on where you are with micro merchandising and whether you think you're getting some benefit there this past quarter?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So as you know, we completed the rollout of micro merchandising in the second half of last year. We've now had it running for about a season and a half. We're very happy with it. We will wait for it would take a couple of years for it to have a full impac
componenttext: So as you know, we completed the rollout of micro merchandising in the second half of last year. We've now had it running for about a season and a half. We're very happy with it. We will wait for it would take a couple of years for it to have a full impact. But the early signs are that it's helping. Our performance has been so strong and there have been so many drivers of that performance, like the lower inventory, the economy, the merchandise we have. And it's hard to separate out the impact of micro merchandising, but I can see it right there now [ph] (42:23).

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010

componenttext: And then one other question. In the first quarter, a lot of data out there about increased tax refunds and other government stimuli. Can you give us a sense for, especially the dd's business, do you feel like that gave you some abnormal benefit in the quarter that you may not be trying to plan for, for the rest of the year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard for us to tell if we got any specific benefit out of it. So it's not affecting how we plan.
componenttext: It's hard for us to tell if we got any specific benefit out of it. So it's not affecting how we plan.

componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about marketing? What's new or different there and the investment spend that's going on? And then also, as you think about your inventory, packaway versus at-once buys, is it different at dd's versus Ross and what's the impact on the margin rebate?

componenttext: First question on marketing, Dana, there's nothing dramatically changed in terms of marketing. I mean, our marketing as you know, that just reminds the customers that come in that we have great bargains. In terms of growth of marketing, each year as we add stores, we take up our marketing proportionately. And every year, that marketing is disproportionately in the back half of the year. So it's the same pattern this year.

componenttext: In terms of packaway and how we view packaway, I think that was the question at dd's versus Ross, we view it exactly the same. We packaway the best bargains that we can find. If there are plenty there, we'll use packaway dollars for it. If in fact, it's a lean period of time, we will carry less. So it's the same methodology.
