componenttext: On your first question, Brian, regarding the margin compares, we still believe there is some room in margin. We are aggressively managing inventories in the back half, so our guidance does contemplate some improvement in margin. However, in the back half, that improved margin will be offset by delevering of expenses based on the lower comp rates.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Brian, on your question about dd's. Dd's actually is still ahead for the year, year-to-date. They just slowed down slightly in the second quarter, but I think dd's is up against pretty strong comparisons from last year. There was one final bit to
componenttext: And then Brian, on your question about dd's. Dd's actually is still ahead for the year, year-to-date. They just slowed down slightly in the second quarter, but I think dd's is up against pretty strong comparisons from last year. There was one final bit to your question, could you just repeat what it was?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Where are you guys on your store lease signings for next year? How many dd's are you guys contemplating when you think about your overall square footage growth rate for next year?
componenttext: Where are you guys on your store lease signings for next year? How many dd's are you guys contemplating when you think about your overall square footage growth rate for next year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a company, overall, we expect around about a 7% unit growth next year. Dd's would probably be about 1 to 2 points of that, so maybe 15-ish kind stores, something about, in that order.
componenttext: As a company, overall, we expect around about a 7% unit growth next year. Dd's would probably be about 1 to 2 points of that, so maybe 15-ish kind stores, something about, in that order.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine with Cowen and Company.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: It looks like -- first, I'd like to clarify, that was about 7% unit growth next year? Is that what you had mentioned, Mike?
componenttext: It looks like -- first, I'd like to clarify, that was about 7% unit growth next year? Is that what you had mentioned, Mike?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Laura, for planning purposes, I would say around about that. I think we've said in the past, our unit growth over the next few years will be in the order of 6% to 7%.
componenttext: Laura, for planning purposes, I would say around about that. I think we've said in the past, our unit growth over the next few years will be in the order of 6% to 7%.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Laura, this is John. We'll get final on those numbers, January timeframe, we'll come out with our guidance for the next year. But I think Michael, just in order of magnitude, that's what we're looking at.
componenttext: Laura, this is John. We'll get final on those numbers, January timeframe, we'll come out with our guidance for the next year. But I think Michael, just in order of magnitude, that's what we're looking at.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And it does seem like, if I heard your EBIT guidance for Q3 right, you'll have a deceleration in the margin that's fairly significant of 8.8% was at the high end of that and then SG&A expense dollar growth likely rose or increases sequentially. What's dri
componenttext: And it does seem like, if I heard your EBIT guidance for Q3 right, you'll have a deceleration in the margin that's fairly significant of 8.8% was at the high end of that and then SG&A expense dollar growth likely rose or increases sequentially. What's driving that increase in SG&A expense dollar growth year-on-year in Q3?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The real factor in the third quarter is there was a 100 basis point benefit last year where we see it from the shrink benefits. We haven't dialed any benefit in from this year's shrinks so we're up against 100 basis points. If you subtract that from the 9
componenttext: The real factor in the third quarter is there was a 100 basis point benefit last year where we see it from the shrink benefits. We haven't dialed any benefit in from this year's shrinks so we're up against 100 basis points. If you subtract that from the 9.9 that we did last year, you get about right in the high end approach at that level. So SG&A increases slightly, but not that meaningfully.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak with SP Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak with SP Research.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the industry, are you beginning to see some inventory cancellations? And are you thinking that the larger in transits that are out there could lead to more cancellations that might benefit you? What are you seeing in the pricing environment? You guys m
componenttext: On the industry, are you beginning to see some inventory cancellations? And are you thinking that the larger in transits that are out there could lead to more cancellations that might benefit you? What are you seeing in the pricing environment? You guys made some comments in July about the competitive environment. I'm noticing your August guidance is an uptick in trend from July, so kind of curious there. And then finally, on California, have you noticed something sort of more in the last couple of months, more of a slowdown? And are you noticing anything different between Northern and Southern?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the inventory cancellations, I would say we've seen an uptick in cancellations that whether it relates to the freight disruption or not, it's hard to tell or just the fact that business has been a little more erratic across mainstream retailers on a mo
componenttext: On the inventory cancellations, I would say we've seen an uptick in cancellations that whether it relates to the freight disruption or not, it's hard to tell or just the fact that business has been a little more erratic across mainstream retailers on a monthly basis, but there has been an uptick. And also, any disruption in flow, which I think is what you're alluding to with the shipping situation, is any disruption of flow is usually a positive for the off-price community. What we've seen in pricing is, certainly, in the second quarter was extremely promotional. And obviously, our guidance has been cautious because we don't know if that's going to continue or not through the rest of the year, but we have to be conservative, and hopefully, we'll do better. But pricing has been interesting in the department store sector over the last several months.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Stacy, I think your last question was about California. In all of the regions that we're in, we break down performance by market. And yes, there are some markets in California that are doing better than others, but I think overall, the performan
componenttext: And then, Stacy, I think your last question was about California. In all of the regions that we're in, we break down performance by market. And yes, there are some markets in California that are doing better than others, but I think overall, the performance in California is kind of how we described in Michael's remarks. I wouldn't pick a part in any individual markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the August guidance, is any of the firming there, does it have to do with better pricing from department stores? Or why are you seeing an uptick in your run rate in August?
componenttext: On the August guidance, is any of the firming there, does it have to do with better pricing from department stores? Or why are you seeing an uptick in your run rate in August?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We really wouldn't comment...
componenttext: We really wouldn't comment...

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Stacy, we really don't comment on sales this month. We did say coming out of July, we saw the trend increase slightly. We'll leave it at that.
componenttext: Stacy, we really don't comment on sales this month. We did say coming out of July, we saw the trend increase slightly. We'll leave it at that.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman with Wells Fargo.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One is on your longer-term EPS growth goals. I believe historically -- and correct me if I'm wrong, maybe it was in the low-double digits. With the significant improvement in your merchandise margins, is there any change to that goal longer
componenttext: Two questions. One is on your longer-term EPS growth goals. I believe historically -- and correct me if I'm wrong, maybe it was in the low-double digits. With the significant improvement in your merchandise margins, is there any change to that goal longer term? And then the second question is, with your packaway, how do you think about that in kind of, this rising cost environment? Is that a benefit for you? Do you think about buying even more ahead of time, ahead of all the cost increases? How do you think about that?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Evren, this is John. On your first question relative to our long-term EPS targets, what we have targeted is, say 10% to 14%, 15% of long term. The improvements in merchandise margin really haven't affected us that much. That goal is really a function of t
componenttext: Evren, this is John. On your first question relative to our long-term EPS targets, what we have targeted is, say 10% to 14%, 15% of long term. The improvements in merchandise margin really haven't affected us that much. That goal is really a function of top line growth, a comp assumption, some EBIT improvement assumptions and a stock repurchase. So that really hasn't, that perspective hasn't changed.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how we think about packaway, in any environment, we think about packaway as the quality of each buy and the value that we think we can purchase it at, and how that fits into our expectations for our assortments for the following season. And so packawa
componenttext: And how we think about packaway, in any environment, we think about packaway as the quality of each buy and the value that we think we can purchase it at, and how that fits into our expectations for our assortments for the following season. And so packaway is surely, purely, regardless of the economic situation, a quality of each individual buy.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you're not increasing earlier buys to kind of ahead potential cost increases?
componenttext: So you're not increasing earlier buys to kind of ahead potential cost increases?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: If the buy looks appropriate, the answer would be  yes. If it doesn't look appropriate, the answer would be no. We don't take a strategy -- we don't really have a strategy that might be cost increases that we're going to buy more packaway. Again, our pack
componenttext: If the buy looks appropriate, the answer would be  yes. If it doesn't look appropriate, the answer would be no. We don't take a strategy -- we don't really have a strategy that might be cost increases that we're going to buy more packaway. Again, our packaway levels are result of the quality of inventory we're able to purchase in the marketplace.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you think about comps, because obviously you're seeing traffic to be a big driver of comps. More recently, it looks like it's more split between traffic and ticket driving comps. So going forward, help us reconcile if the department store theme as if
componenttext: When you think about comps, because obviously you're seeing traffic to be a big driver of comps. More recently, it looks like it's more split between traffic and ticket driving comps. So going forward, help us reconcile if the department store theme as if they're a bit more promotional, how we should think about the ticket opportunities, especially as you lap some easy year-ago comparisons there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the ticket comparisons, as you said, we were up slightly in the quarter. Interest was up slightly, and it probably speaks to our pricing where we believe that we're delivering pretty good values. We're confident about how we're going in the third qu
componenttext: So on the ticket comparisons, as you said, we were up slightly in the quarter. Interest was up slightly, and it probably speaks to our pricing where we believe that we're delivering pretty good values. We're confident about how we're going in the third quarter. So if department stores  decide to get more promotional, that might hurt on the traffic a bit like we saw in the springtime, but we do believe we're pretty well set for the third quarter.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you kind of walk in terms of the traffic trends? Have you seen some -- maybe talk us through sort of the traffic trends you saw in the quarter? And how you expect that to play out in the third quarter?
componenttext: Could you kind of walk in terms of the traffic trends? Have you seen some -- maybe talk us through sort of the traffic trends you saw in the quarter? And how you expect that to play out in the third quarter?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the traffic trend were reflected in the comp, which is a pretty good guide to the traffic trends. So if you take our comp assumptions for the third quarter, there's a lot of uniformity in that versus traffic.
componenttext: So the traffic trend were reflected in the comp, which is a pretty good guide to the traffic trends. So if you take our comp assumptions for the third quarter, there's a lot of uniformity in that versus traffic.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as it relates to the categories because we've been hearing Dress and Shoes has been a strong driver for some time. Can you give us some sense in terms of where you're seeing some opportunities in other categories or pretty consistent with what's
componenttext: And then as it relates to the categories because we've been hearing Dress and Shoes has been a strong driver for some time. Can you give us some sense in terms of where you're seeing some opportunities in other categories or pretty consistent with what's been strong so far?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's pretty consistent. The big swing is that it's been a very good buying opportunity. So we'll see how that plays out across all the other categories. But those three businesses have been uniquely strong for us for a period of time: Dress, Shoes
componenttext: I think it's pretty consistent. The big swing is that it's been a very good buying opportunity. So we'll see how that plays out across all the other categories. But those three businesses have been uniquely strong for us for a period of time: Dress, Shoes and Home.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dave Weiner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dave Weiner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll ask about your growth into new markets next year. So within that 7% square footage growth that you called out, can you kind of give a little detail as to how much of that is the new markets? And has there been any change over the last quarter or so i
componenttext: I'll ask about your growth into new markets next year. So within that 7% square footage growth that you called out, can you kind of give a little detail as to how much of that is the new markets? And has there been any change over the last quarter or so in terms of the pace at which you roll out in those markets?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, I think we've said in the past that we will enter new markets in 2011. I think the important thing to keep in mind is, at least, for the new few years, we're now talking about the number of stores won't be material in terms of the overall impact on
componenttext: Dave, I think we've said in the past that we will enter new markets in 2011. I think the important thing to keep in mind is, at least, for the new few years, we're now talking about the number of stores won't be material in terms of the overall impact on company growth. Of that 7% unit growth, it would be no more than a point or two that will be in new market, so the financial impact on the company over the next few years won't be that significant.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And any comments on kind of geographies that could be starting in the Midwest or then move your way East?
componenttext: And any comments on kind of geographies that could be starting in the Midwest or then move your way East?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're looking at all of that now. Obviously, we're already in 27 states, so there's quite a lot of opportunity for us. So we're going to the first test of evaluating the right roll-out plan.
componenttext: We're looking at all of that now. Obviously, we're already in 27 states, so there's quite a lot of opportunity for us. So we're going to the first test of evaluating the right roll-out plan.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Sean Naughton with Piper Jaffrey.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Sean Naughton with Piper Jaffrey.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about the slowdown in comps at dd's, obviously, up against some fiscal comparisons. But can you talk about any impact that you saw when the extended unemployment benefits wore off at the end of June? And was there a snapback in the comps when t
componenttext: You talked about the slowdown in comps at dd's, obviously, up against some fiscal comparisons. But can you talk about any impact that you saw when the extended unemployment benefits wore off at the end of June? And was there a snapback in the comps when those were reinstituted in July?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The slowdown that we referred to was in the second quarter and the event you just referenced was in the second quarter, but it's hard for us to draw a sort of causal relationship. I think the unemployment benefits have only just been reinstituted, so it's
componenttext: The slowdown that we referred to was in the second quarter and the event you just referenced was in the second quarter, but it's hard for us to draw a sort of causal relationship. I think the unemployment benefits have only just been reinstituted, so it's hard for us to tell if that will have an impact. So we agree that no, it  could be one of the number of factors that could contribute to dd's performance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it doesn't seem like there was a fall off on those, kind of when rolled off that, that's not what you guys saw necessarily in the context?
componenttext: So it doesn't seem like there was a fall off on those, kind of when rolled off that, that's not what you guys saw necessarily in the context?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We just can't draw a link between the two. Dd's did see a slowdown in second quarter as we've said. But we don't know what part of that...
componenttext: We just can't draw a link between the two. Dd's did see a slowdown in second quarter as we've said. But we don't know what part of that...

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then gross margins, obviously, you guys are doing a great job in keeping inventories tight and executing positive same-store sales. But can you talk about -- and you mentioned that California was improving from the micro-merchandise initiatives. But h
componenttext: And then gross margins, obviously, you guys are doing a great job in keeping inventories tight and executing positive same-store sales. But can you talk about -- and you mentioned that California was improving from the micro-merchandise initiatives. But have you been able to drill down any further on what the potential is for further merchandise margin expansions or how much has been contributed to this particular initiative?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's very hard to tell because micro-merchandising was launched about a year ago, and we're pretty happy with how it's working. And obviously, over the course of the past year, we've seen pretty significant improvements in that margin. But there have been
componenttext: It's very hard to tell because micro-merchandising was launched about a year ago, and we're pretty happy with how it's working. And obviously, over the course of the past year, we've seen pretty significant improvements in that margin. But there have been a number of things that have contributed to that, the lower inventory levels, the fact that our sales continue to run ahead of plan, so it's hard for us to isolate this particular variable. We think it's helping, but it's hard for us to calibrate exactly how much.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly on Florida, clearly, this has been called out as an area of strength for you guys recently. Is there anything that you can talk about and to why this particular area or this part of the chain is really outperforming? Is there a category or have you
componenttext: Lastly on Florida, clearly, this has been called out as an area of strength for you guys recently. Is there anything that you can talk about and to why this particular area or this part of the chain is really outperforming? Is there a category or have you changed your marketing strategy in this area? Or are these jut coming up some relatively easier comparisons and they're just getting a little bit more of a lift?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's the latter. I don't think we've reinvented the wheel there. I think were up against a couple of soft years, and we're getting some share back.
componenttext: I think it's the latter. I don't think we've reinvented the wheel there. I think were up against a couple of soft years, and we're getting some share back.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes to the line of David Mann with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes to the line of David Mann with Johnson Rice.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to the question about your August guidance. You've talked about how it's a little, I guess, easier compare against last year, but looks like it's a little tougher when you go back two or three years. I'm just curious what your thoughts on that,
componenttext: Going back to the question about your August guidance. You've talked about how it's a little, I guess, easier compare against last year, but looks like it's a little tougher when you go back two or three years. I'm just curious what your thoughts on that, in terms of why you're more bullish on August?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, this is John. Obviously, we can see where we are. As I've mentioned, we came out in July strongly. We like where we are in August. And given the compares you talked about, that informed our guidance relative to August.
componenttext: David, this is John. Obviously, we can see where we are. As I've mentioned, we came out in July strongly. We like where we are in August. And given the compares you talked about, that informed our guidance relative to August.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other point is back-to-school obviously is an important time for the customer. It's the time they need to go out and shop. So if I was to entrance that with July, which is a much quieter time and not a  lot of reason for the customer to go out there.
componenttext: The other point is back-to-school obviously is an important time for the customer. It's the time they need to go out and shop. So if I was to entrance that with July, which is a much quieter time and not a  lot of reason for the customer to go out there. And if there are deals and there's concerns, that's what we feel like, August is an opportunity.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then John, in terms of SG&A, can you just give us a sense on how you think about the back half in terms of the comp leverage point for SG&A?
componenttext: And then John, in terms of SG&A, can you just give us a sense on how you think about the back half in terms of the comp leverage point for SG&A?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I did mention that we will experience a slight deleverage in SG&A in the back half on the 1 to 2 1/3 and flat to down to one in the fourth quarter. So our leverage point now, David, I probably think it's right around 2%, 3% for SG&A.
componenttext: Sure. I did mention that we will experience a slight deleverage in SG&A in the back half on the 1 to 2 1/3 and flat to down to one in the fourth quarter. So our leverage point now, David, I probably think it's right around 2%, 3% for SG&A.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Marni Shapiro with Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Marni Shapiro with Retail Tracker.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you guys could just talk about, you have a lot of moving parts in the store, a lot of different segments, besides for just Women's apparel? Can you talk about any segments that maybe surprise you to the positive or negative that you can
componenttext: I was wondering if you guys could just talk about, you have a lot of moving parts in the store, a lot of different segments, besides for just Women's apparel? Can you talk about any segments that maybe surprise you to the positive or negative that you can chase into the fall and holiday season?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, could you repeat that? You broke up a little.
componenttext: I'm sorry, could you repeat that? You broke up a little.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was curious if there are any segments, you have a lot of different segments between Kids, Non-Apparel, Misses, Juniors, Men's, Shoes. Any segment that surprise you to the positive or negative that you can chase into the fall or holiday season?
componenttext: I was curious if there are any segments, you have a lot of different segments between Kids, Non-Apparel, Misses, Juniors, Men's, Shoes. Any segment that surprise you to the positive or negative that you can chase into the fall or holiday season?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's segments within Apparel. Certainly, both in Juniors and Young Men's that we could chase, and we're very happy with our set of Core business and its chasing potential wear.
componenttext: Well, I think there's segments within Apparel. Certainly, both in Juniors and Young Men's that we could chase, and we're very happy with our set of Core business and its chasing potential wear.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: You guys have shown really good operating discipline in regards to your inventory last several years. Wondering, at what point with the year of micro-merchandising under your belt, does that kind of run out of steam when you start operating with,  rather
componenttext: You guys have shown really good operating discipline in regards to your inventory last several years. Wondering, at what point with the year of micro-merchandising under your belt, does that kind of run out of steam when you start operating with,  rather than declining inventories year-over-year, that start to see that flatten? And I guess, if you want to comment on the next couple of quarters, that would be great or if you just want to comment more generally about how you see that unfolding?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, our inventory, we feel good about how we've been managing it. I appreciate your kind comments, but our view is that we put things in place with micro-merchandising, so we can plan better from a localized level. It gives us another tool to keep
componenttext: Basically, our inventory, we feel good about how we've been managing it. I appreciate your kind comments, but our view is that we put things in place with micro-merchandising, so we can plan better from a localized level. It gives us another tool to keep digging out inventory that we don't need. So I think there's still room to go. And when there isn't, I don't see us plowing a lot more inventories. I think we've learned a lot over the last few years that we'll be applying forever in this company.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I didn't mean to imply that it was time to start building inventory, just wondering how much more opportunity, obviously the big gains that they made in terms of inventory reduction. I'm just wondering if there's still more opportunity?
componenttext: I didn't mean to imply that it was time to start building inventory, just wondering how much more opportunity, obviously the big gains that they made in terms of inventory reduction. I'm just wondering if there's still more opportunity?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think there is, we think there's still more opportunity.
componenttext: We think there is, we think there's still more opportunity.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in the back half, we think inventories will be that high singles.
componenttext: And in the back half, we think inventories will be that high singles.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are no further questions at this time. I'll turn the call back over to our presenters.
componenttext: There are no further questions at this time. I'll turn the call back over to our presenters.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We want to thank you all for your interest in Ross. We look forward to speaking to you all again in November. Have a great day.
componenttext: We want to thank you all for your interest in Ross. We look forward to speaking to you all again in November. Have a great day.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, that concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator In
componenttext: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Balmuth.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on our call are: Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice P
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on our call are: Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director of Investor Relations. We'll begin with a brief review of our third quarter performance followed by our outlook for the remainder of the year. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
Before we begin, I want to note that our comments on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results and other matters that are based on management's current forecast of aspects of the company's future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. These risk factors are detailed in today's press release and our fiscal 2009 Form 10-K, and 2010 Form 10-Qs and 8-Ks on file with the SEC. 
Today, we reported third quarter earnings of $1.02, up from $0.84 per share for the 2009 third quarter. These results represent a 21% increase on top of exceptional growth in the prior year when earnings per share were up 91%. Net earnings for the current year quarter grew 16% to a record $121.4 million, up from $105.1 million last year. 
Our third quarter sales increased 7% to $1,874,000,000, with comparable store sales up a better than expected 3% on top of an 8% gain in the prior year. For the nine months ended October 30, 2010, earnings per share were $3.26, up from $2.39 for the same period in 2009. These results represent a 36% increase on top of a robust 52% gain in earnings per share during the first nine months of last year. Year-to-date through October 30, net earnings grew 31% to a record $393 million, up from $299.9 million last year.
Sales for the first nine months of 2010 increased 10% to $5,721,000,000, with comparable store sales up 6% versus a 5% gain for the same period in 2009. We delivered strong sales and earnings increases in the third quarter and first nine months of 2010, on top of outstanding gains in the prior year. This is especially noteworthy considering the ongoing uncertainty in the macroeconomic and retail environment.
Our third quarter performance was driven by our continued ability to deliver exciting bargains while operating our business on lower inventories, as well as much better than expected shortage results. Dresses and Home were the top performing merchandise categories for the third quarter, both with low double-digit same-store sales increases. 
Geographic trends were relatively broad based. Florida remained the strongest region with low double-digit comparable store sales gains for the third quarter and first nine months. We are pleased to report that sales trends in California improved during the quarter. Despite ongoing weakness in the housing market and high unemployment, same store sales in our largest state rose 2% in the third quarter, on top of an 8% increase in the prior year. Year-to-date, California is up 3% on top of a 5% gain last year.
For the third quarter and first nine months, profit margins rose to new record levels on top of exceptional gains in the prior year. Earnings before interest and taxes as a percent of sales grew to 10.5% in the quarter for a 60 basis point increase on top of a 385 basis point gain in the same period last year. 
Gross margin rose 80 basis points as higher merchandise gross margin, lower distribution cost and leverage on occupancy expenses were partially offset mainly by higher incentive and freight costs as a percent of sales versus the prior year. Selling, general and administrative expenses grew 20 basis points, mainly due to higher incentive cost as a percent of sales. John will provide some additional details on these operating margin trends in a few minutes.
As we ended the third quarter, total consolidated inventories were up about 3% with average selling store inventory down about 10%. Packaway was about 37% of total inventories compared to 32% at this time last year. We continue to plan further reductions of in-store inventories with average levels targeted down in the high single-digit percentage range in the fourth quarter compared to 2009. As we have mentioned on previous calls, our ongoing focus on tight inventory management allows us to maximize the percentage of fresh receipts the customers use while shopping our stores. It also drives faster inventory turns, fewer markdowns, and ultimately, higher merchandise gross margin.
Turning to our store expansion program. We added 12 Ross and 10 dd's DISCOUNTS stores in the most recent quarter, and ended the period with 1,057 combined locations in 27 states in Guam. 
dd's DISCOUNTS sales trends improved during the third quarter with positive comparable store sales increases on top of exceptionally strong prior year results. As I mentioned, we opened 10 dd stores in the period including entry into the Atlanta market. Year-to-date, we have added 15 locations and now operate 67 dd's DISCOUNTS stores in six states. 
Based on our year-to-date results and outlook for the fourth quarter, we continue to expect dd's DISCOUNTS to be slightly profitable in 2010 before allocations for corporate expense. Now let's talk about our financial condition.
Our balance sheet and cash flows remain healthy and we ended the quarter with $735 million of cash and short-term investments. Our cash position continues to benefit from better-than-expected earnings and reduced working capital needs as we operate the business on lower inventories. During the third quarter and first nine months of 2010, we repurchased 1.7 million and 5.4 million shares of our common stock, respectively, for an aggregate purchase price of $287 million year-to-date. We remain on track to complete, during 2010, approximately $375 million of our current two-year $750 million stock repurchase program.
I'd like to turn now to our updated outlook for the fourth quarter. As we noted in today's press release, we are solidly positioned as a value retailer, and our stores are stocked with fresh and exciting merchandise. That said, while we have outperformed our projections year-to-date, there are a number of reasons why we believe it is prudent to maintain a cautious outlook for the fourth quarter.
It still remains difficult to predict the future in today's uncertain macro economic and retail climate. We also see the likelihood of a very promotional and competitive holiday season this year, combined with the fact that we are up against our toughest prior year sales comparison as well as robust earnings growth. In last year's fourth quarter, same-store sales grew 10% and earnings per share rose 53%. In addition, the timing of Christmas Day means that we have one less Saturday of business in our largest volume month of the year. As a result, while we hope to do better, we are maintaining our prior forecast for both sales and earnings in the 2010 fourth quarter.
Now John will provide additional color on our third quarter results and details of our fourth quarter guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Our 3% comparable store sales gain in the third quarter was driven by a combination of low single-digit increases in both the number of transactions and in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin improved by about 60 ba
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Our 3% comparable store sales gain in the third quarter was driven by a combination of low single-digit increases in both the number of transactions and in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin improved by about 60 basis points in the quarter to 10.5%, driven by an 80 basis point increase in gross margin, partially offset by a 20 basis point rise in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales. 
Merchandise market increased about 85 basis points, mainly due to faster inventory turns that resulted in lower markdowns. As we noted with our September sales release, the shortage results from our annual physical inventory of stores were much better than expected and added about $0.10 in earnings per share to our third quarter 2010 results. 
Distribution costs declined about 50 basis points, while occupancy expense benefited the quarter by about 15 basis points. These favorable comparisons were partially offset mainly by 60 basis points in higher buying and incentive costs and a 10 basis point increase in freight expense. The 20 basis point increase in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales is mainly due to higher incentive expenses. Our buyback program drove a 5% reduction in diluted shares outstanding, and a slightly lower tax rate added about 2% to net earnings growth in the quarter.
Turning now to our guidance for the fourth quarter. Again, for the reasons Michael just mentioned, while we hope to do better, we believe it is prudent in this environment to stay somewhat cautious as we plan our business for the holiday season. For the 13 weeks ending January 29, 2011, we continue to forecast comparable store sales to be flat to down 1% on top of our very strong 10% growth in last year's fourth quarter. Earnings per share are projected to be $1.15 to $1.20, compared to $1.16 in the prior year period when earnings per share were up a robust 53%. Our fourth quarter 2010 targets are based on the following assumptions.
Total sales are planned to grow about 3% to 4%, driven by a combination of new store growth, and as mentioned, same-store sales that are flat-to-down 1%. Our guidance assumes that comparable store sales are up 2% to 3% in November, and down 1% to 2% in both December and January. 
Last year's same-store sales rose 8%, 12%, and 8% in November, December and January, respectively. Based on these sales assumptions, operating margins for the fourth quarter is projected to be 11% to 11.2%. This compares to 11.7% in the 2009 fourth quarter. As a percent of sales, we are planning flat to slightly better merchandise gross margin that is projected to be offset by somewhat higher freight costs. 
Due to timing issues on packaway inventories, distribution costs are forecast to increase as a percent of sales in the fourth quarter. Based on our assumptions of flat to down 1% same-store sales, we would also expect to see some deleveraging on occupancy and other selling, general and administrative costs. 
Net interest expense is planned to be approximately $2 million, and our tax rate is expected to be about 38%. We also estimate weighted average diluted shares outstanding of about 118 million. Given our year-to-date performance and projections for the fourth quarter, we now are estimating earnings per share for the fiscal year ending January 29, 2011, to be in the range of $4.41 to $4.46 compared to $3.54 in the 2009 fiscal year. This represents robust projected growth of 25% to 26% on top of the outstanding 52% gain we delivered in fiscal 2009. Now I'll turn the call back to Michael.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. To sum up, we are very pleased with our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance. In addition, even if fourth quarter earnings performed just in line with our guidance, we will be on track to report a record operating margin of 1
componenttext:
Thank you, John. To sum up, we are very pleased with our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance. In addition, even if fourth quarter earnings performed just in line with our guidance, we will be on track to report a record operating margin of 11% or more for fiscal 2010. 
One of the most frequently asked questions we get now is if this current level of profitability is sustainable. We strongly believe that it is, due to a permanent structural change in our business model. Over the past three years, we have made substantial gains in operating margin, driven by the successful implementation of a number of strategic initiatives.
The biggest driver of our improved profitability has been record merchandise gross margin resulting from better buying and the significant reductions we have made in selling store inventories. Off-price buying is our most important business strategy, and we remain committed to making ongoing investments in our merchandise organization. By putting hundreds of Ross and dd's merchants in the market to source product from thousands of vendors, we are maximizing our access to the best bargains available. Going forward, we will continue to invest in this critical area of our business.
We have also been extremely successful over the last few years in operating our business on much lower inventories. Today, selling store inventories are more than 30% lower than they were just three years ago. This sizable reduction has resulted in a much larger percentage of fresh merchandise that the customers use while shopping our stores, which we believe had benefited sales. Lower inventories have also driven much faster inventory turns and a meaningful decline in markdown activity over this period. The implementation of our shortage control initiatives has also benefited margins by dramatically reducing shrink over the past few years to record low levels today.
Other sustainable drivers of operating margin include the numerous productivity enhancements and efficiencies we have implemented throughout the company to drive down cost, including our distribution centers, stores organization and back-office functions. As a result of all these structural changes, we believe that annual operating margin in a low double-digit percentage range is sustainable going forward. 
This gives us the confidence to continue to target, over the longer term, average annual earnings per share growth of 10% to 15%. The formula for achieving this is a combination of unit growth, annual increases in same-store sales and ongoing reduction in diluted shares outstanding from our stock repurchase program.
In closing, we believe that consumers increased focus on pricing value will continue for the foreseeable future, which bodes well for our business. We also know that our ability to give our customers the best bargain possible on a wide array of fashions for the family and the home will always be the most critical factor to our success. 
As a result, we will maintain an unwavering focus on what has worked so well for us over the past few years, solid execution of all our merchandising strategies, along with the continued focus on tight inventory and expense controls. At this point, we would like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

componenttext: I guess our question really on the uses of cash, it seems like if you look at the balance sheet, it seems like you also would have the flexibility to either consider a special dividend that a few companies are doing today or an accelerated share repurchase program. And then as you talk about that in context for square footage growth for 2011, maybe talk about new markets, how much of the store growth next year is going to come in new markets versus existing markets?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Michael O'Sullivan, so I'll take both of those. On the uses of cash, we have a pretty good track record of increasing our dividend and buyback program to return cash to shareholders. So earlier this year, we announced a 45% increase in divi
componenttext: Brian, this is Michael O'Sullivan, so I'll take both of those. On the uses of cash, we have a pretty good track record of increasing our dividend and buyback program to return cash to shareholders. So earlier this year, we announced a 45% increase in dividend and a 25% increase in buyback. And in the January timeframe, we'll take another look at that and make some announcements probably in early 2011 about further increases. On your second question about store growth, I think we've announced previously that in 2011, we'll probably have around about 6% to 7% unit growth for stores. And I would say about 1% to 2% of that would be in new markets. And obviously, that's the prior to income, the revenue cash [ph] by using cash to fuel growth.

componenttext: Just maybe if I could follow up, maybe can you talk about store growth by concept next year? And maybe if you have some initial thoughts on CapEx? And I guess, John, I mean, what's the level of cash that you feel like you need to have on the balance sheet to feel comfortable?

componenttext: So on your question regarding cash flow, as Michael said, we'll make some decisions relative to buyback and dividend as we end the year. We also have some investments to make in distribution centers to provide for the infrastructure we need. So looking at all that, and there'll be more information forthcoming towards the end of the year.

componenttext: I was curious, you have increased your merchant staff quite a bit over the last several years. And I feel like you're in a good place right now, but I'm from the outside looking in. So I'm curious if you can talk a little bit about your merchant staff, both as it relates to Ross stores and dd.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a strategic initiative to grow the staff for a number of years, both the buying staff in both companies, as well as the planning and allocation staff. And we've been watching with the strategy for a number of years as I said and we're goin
componenttext: Well, we've had a strategic initiative to grow the staff for a number of years, both the buying staff in both companies, as well as the planning and allocation staff. And we've been watching with the strategy for a number of years as I said and we're going to continue to do it. It further gives us the ability to segregate businesses, get better market coverage and look for more opportunities in all the marketplaces that we trade in. And we are very comfortable with the strategy. We think it's the key initiative. It is the single key initiative that has enabled us to grow our business the way we have.

componenttext: So Marni (sic) [Adrianne], that's correct. All of the leverage of the 20 basis points did happen on the incentive line. We're extremely profitable during the quarter. And as we look at our business, we did achieve some leverage of occupancy and store expenses that was offset by the incentives, as I mentioned. We expect to deliver for the year, deleverage in SG&A. If we look at the year, that's probably around the four comps. So that's about where it is, depending on timing and other issues.

componenttext: The leverage point is around, like I said this year, we'll have some slight leverage around the four in the quarter. We did lever on the three. As you go next year, depending on how we do and from a topline standpoint, we're thinking that 3-ish is probably the leverage point that they would probably achieve.

componenttext: Sure. That is in the 85 basis points of margin improvement. Having said that, we achieved 100 basis points of margin improvement in the prior year. So we're up against 100 basis points. In the 85 basis points, we actually lapped 10 basis points on the compare.

componenttext: The other point to make is just from an EPS point of view, Kimberly. The balance in Q3 was about $0.10. Last year, it was at $0.11. So obviously, we got benefit on top of benefit. When you look at it on a margin basis, it's a little bit confusing. But I think it's clear when you look at it on a dollar basis.

componenttextpreview: It changed slightly. So historically, the past couple of years, we've grown the store base lower than 6% to 7%. So it' more around 4% to 5%. And we'd assume some operating margin improvement with the repurchase. So it gets between 10% and 15%. We're incre
componenttext: It changed slightly. So historically, the past couple of years, we've grown the store base lower than 6% to 7%. So it' more around 4% to 5%. And we'd assume some operating margin improvement with the repurchase. So it gets between 10% and 15%. We're increasing our top line of 6% to 7%, we are assuming that we're sustaining churn operating margin level in that long-term model. Add at, say, three comps to that and 4% earnings growth based on repurchase activities, we get between the 10% and 15% earnings growth per year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttext: And then in terms of unit growth, the 6% to 7% per year, we were listening to the TJX conference call and I think they talked about accelerating Marmaxx openings in the U.S., especially in Manhattan, I think taking advantage of some of the real estate opportunities. componenttext: No. We're going to stick to the 6% to 7% growth. Obviously, we'll be opportunistic in terms of what locations we pick up and what kind of real estate deals we do. But I think you can expect 6% to 7% as far as going to be.

componenttextpreview: Given all the commentary out there about apparel inflation that is on its way. I'm just curious, Michael, when you look back in history, in periods of inflation, what do you think that means for you in terms of availability of goods?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttext: It's kind of hard to predict. I mean, what's going on in the apparel manufacturing cycle is in the early stage. So we don't exactly know how this is going to land. But periods of disruption in pricing create uncertainty in the whole supply line, create some uncertainty at mainstream retailing, and historically, has been good for us in access of products.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttext: And then in terms of the deals that you bought, the increase in packaway, should we expect to see that you might have an opportunity to use that to drive merchandise margin just given that you're going to be selling a lot of that merchandise in a period when other retailers can be raising their prices?

componenttext: I think you should assume it will help us in some way in sales. It wouldn't hurt us and margin packaway is usually a high-margin product for us under normal circumstances. So depending on how this all shakes out, it could be a positive, but it's really, as I said, too early to tell that aspect though.

componenttext: On the retail square footage growth going forward, are you seeing anything in terms of changes with respect to cost and/or availability of real estate? And how is that kind of playing into your acceleration plans? And the second one, just be on this inflationary pressure, cost of goods pressure in the categories, both domestics and apparel, how does that play into your strategy of packaway? Are you taking advantage of some categories in front of the price increases or is this normal course of business?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the packaway one first. We purchased packaway based on the quality of each unique buy. And what we think the value of that product is based on the brand and the classification of merchandise. We don't think a packaway is a hedge against inflat
componenttext: Let me take the packaway one first. We purchased packaway based on the quality of each unique buy. And what we think the value of that product is based on the brand and the classification of merchandise. We don't think a packaway is a hedge against inflation. We think of packaway as pure merchandise opportunities that we think our customers will value. If it turns out to be a hedge against inflation, great. But that's not our unique packaway strategy.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on your question, Jeff, about real estate opportunities, certainly, we don't think that's happened in the real estate market, the real state market the last couple of years. There are opportunities out there in terms of locations and in terms of
componenttext: And then on your question, Jeff, about real estate opportunities, certainly, we don't think that's happened in the real estate market, the real state market the last couple of years. There are opportunities out there in terms of locations and in terms of negotiating good deals. And needless to say, we're using more leverage we can to go up with those opportunities.

But the other aspects of the economic model obviously will play in terms of sales and so forth. [indiscernible].

componenttext: Just a follow-up on the inventory, as inventory turns more quickly and you've got a bigger team out in the field, is the focus on packaway diminishing and the idea being buying closer to need and buying with more market intelligence as it were? headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The strategy is to be flexible. So when packaway opportunities are plentiful, we raise it as we are now. And when there are less of lesser quality, we shrink the level. And that's what drives its penetration for our total inventory level.
componenttext: The strategy is to be flexible. So when packaway opportunities are plentiful, we raise it as we are now. And when there are less of lesser quality, we shrink the level. And that's what drives its penetration for our total inventory level.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores third quarter 2010 earnings release conference call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. (Operator in
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores third quarter 2010 earnings release conference call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions) As a reminder, ladies and gentlemen, this conference is being recorded today November 18, 2010
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Balmuth.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on our call are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O’Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on our call are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O’Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director of Investor Relations.
We’ll begin with a brief review of our third quarter performance followed by our outlook for the remainder of the year. Afterwards, we’ll be happy to respond to any questions you may have.
Before we begin, I want to note that our comments on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results and other matters that are based on management’s current forecast of aspects of the company’s future business.
These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. These risk factors are detailed in today’s press release and our fiscal 2009 Form 10-K and 2010 Form 10-Qs and 8-Ks on file with the SEC.
Today, we reported third quarter earnings of $1.02, up from $0.84 per share for the 2009 third quarter. These results represent a 21% increase on top of exceptional growth in the prior year, when earnings per share were up 91%. Net earnings for the current year quarter grew 16% to a record $121.4 million, up from $105.1 million last year.
Our third quarter sales increased 7% to $1.874 billion, with comparable store sales up a better than expected 3% on top of an 8% gain in the prior year. For the nine months ended October 30, 2010, earnings per share were $3.26, up from $2.39 for the same period in 2009.
These results represent a 36% increase on top of a robust 52% gain in earnings per share during the first nine months of last year. Year-to-date through October 30, net earnings grew 31% to a record $393 million, up from $299.9 million last year.
Sales for the first nine months of 2010 increased 10% to $5.721 billion with comparable store sales up 6% versus a 5% gain for the same period in 2009. We delivered strong sales and earnings increases in the third quarter and first nine months of 2010 on top of outstanding gains in the prior year. This is especially noteworthy considering the ongoing uncertainty in the macroeconomic and retail environment.
Our third quarter performance was driven by our continued ability to deliver exciting bargains while operating our business on lower inventories as well as much better than expect shortage results.
Dresses and Home were the top performing merchandise categories for the third quarter, both with low double-digit same stores sales increases. Geographic trends were relatively broad-based.
Florida remained the strongest region with low double-digit comparable store sales gains for the third quarter and first nine months. We are pleased to report that sales trends in California improved during the quarter.
Despite ongoing weakness in the housing market and high unemployment, same-store sales in our largest state rose 2% in the third quarter on top of an 8% increase in the prior year. Year-to-date, California is up 3% on top of a 5% gain last year.
For the third quarter and first nine months, profit margins rose to new record levels on top of exceptional gains in the prior year. Earnings before interest and taxes as a percent of sales grew to 10.5% in the quarter for a 60 basis point increase on top of a 385 basis point gain in the same period last year.
Gross margin rose 80 basis points as higher merchandise gross margin, lower distribution costs and leverage on occupancy expenses were partially offset, mainly by higher intensive and freight cost as a percent of sales versus the prior year.
Selling, general and administrative expenses grew 20 basis points mainly due to higher incentive costs as a percent of sales. John will provide some additional details on these operating margin trends in a few minutes.
At the end of the third quarter, total consolidated inventories were up about 3% with average selling store inventories down about 10%. Packaway was about 37% of total inventories compared to 32% at this time last year.
We continue to plan further reductions of in-store inventories with average levels targeted down in the high single-digit percentage range in the fourth quarter compared to 2009.
As we have mentioned on previous calls, our ongoing focus on tight inventory management allows us to maximize the percentage of fresh receipts the customer sees while shopping our stores. It also drives faster inventory turns, fewer markdowns and ultimately higher merchandise gross margins.
Turning to our store expansion program, we added 12 Ross and 10 dd’s DISCOUNTS stores in the most recent quarter and ended the period with 1,057 combine locations in 27 states in Guam. Dd’s DISCOUNTS sales trends improved during the third quarter with positive comparable store sales increases on top of exceptionally strong prior year results.
As I mentioned we opened 10 dd’s stores in the period, including entry into the Atlanta market. Year-to-date we have added 15 locations and now operate 67 dd’s DISCOUNTS stores in six states. Based on our year-to-date results and outlook for the fourth quarter, we continue to expect dd’s DISCOUNTS to be slightly profitable in 2010 before allocations for corporate expense.
Now let’s talk about our financial condition. Our balance sheet and cash flows remain healthy and we ended the quarter with $735 million of cash and short-term investments. Our cash position continues to benefit from better than expected earnings and reduced working capital needs, as we operate the business on lower inventories.
Turning to third quarter and first nine months of 2010, we repurchased 1.7 million and 5.4 million shares of our common stock respectively for an aggregate purchase price of $287 million year-to-date. We remain on track to complete during 2010 approximately $375 million of our current two year $750 million stock repurchase program.
I’d like to turn now to our updated outlook for the fourth quarter. As we noted in today’s press release, we are solidly positioned as a value retailer and our stores are stocked with fresh and exciting merchandise.
That said while we have outperformed our projections year-to-date, there are a number of seasons why we believe it is prudent to maintain a cautious outlook for the fourth quarter.
It still remains difficult to predict the future in today’s uncertain macroeconomic and retail climate. We also see the likelihood of a very promotional and competitive holiday season this year combined with the fact that we are up against our toughest prior year sales comparison as well as robust earnings growth.
In last year’s fourth quarter, same store sales grew 10% and earnings per share rose 53%. In addition the timing of the Christmas day means that we have one less Saturday of business in our largest volume month of the year. As a result, while we hope to do better, we are maintaining our prior forecast of both sales and earnings in 2010 fourth quarter.
Now, John will provide additional color on our third quarter results and details of our fourth quarter guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. On our 3% comparable store sales gain in the third quarter was driven by a combination of low single digit increases in both the number of transactions and in the size of the average baskets.Again, operating margin improved by about
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. On our 3% comparable store sales gain in the third quarter was driven by a combination of low single digit increases in both the number of transactions and in the size of the average baskets.
Again, operating margin improved by about 60 basis points in the quarter to 10.5% driven by an 80 basis point increase in gross margins, partially offset by a 20 basis point drive in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales. Merchandise margin increased about 85 basis points, mainly due to faster inventory turns that resulted in lower mark-up.
As we noted with our September sales release, the shortage results from our annual physical inventory of stores were much better-than-expected and added about $0.10 in earnings per share to our third quarter 2010 results.
Distribution comps declined about 50 basis points while occupancy expense benefited the quarter by about 15 basis points. These favorable comparisons were partially offset mainly by 50 basis points in higher buying and incentive comp and a 10 basis point increase in freight expense.
The 20 basis point increase in selling, general and administrative cost as a percent of sales was mainly due to higher incentive expenses. Our buyback program drove a 5% reduction in diluted shares outstanding and a slightly lower tax rate added about 2% to net earnings growth in the quarter.
Turning now to our guidance for the fourth quarter; again for the reasons Michael just mentioned, while we hope to do better we believe it is prudent in this environment to stay somewhat cautious as we plan our business for the holiday season.
For the 13-weeks ending January 29, 2011, we continue to forecast a comparable store sales to be flat to down 1% on top of our very strong 10% growth in last year’s fourth quarter.
Earnings per share are projected to be $1.15 to $1.20 compared to $1.16 in the prior year period when earnings per share were up, a robust 53%.
Our fourth quarter 2010 targets are based on the following assumptions. Total sales are planned to grow about 3% to 4%, driven by a combination of new store growth, and as mentioned, same store sales that are flat to down 1%. Our guidance assumes that comparables store sales are up 2% to 3% in November and down 1% to 2% in both December and January.
Last year, same-store sales rose 8%, 12% and 8% in November, December and January respectively. Based on these sales assumptions, operating margin for the fourth quarter is projected to be 11% to 11.2%, this compares to 11.7% in the 2009 fourth quarter.
As a percent of sales, we are planning flat to slightly better merchandise gross margin that is projected to be offset by somewhat higher freight costs. Due to timing issues on packaway inventory, distribution costs are forecast to increase as a percent of sales in the fourth quarter.
Based on our assumptions, a flat to down 1% same-store sales, we would also expect to see some deleveraging on occupancy and other selling, general and administrative cost.
Net interest expense is planned to be approximately $2 million and our tax rate is expected to be about 38%. We also estimate weighted average diluted shares outstanding of about $118 million.
Given our year-to-date performance and projections for the fourth quarter, we now are estimating earnings per share for the fiscal year ending January 29, 2011 to be in the range of $4.41 to $4.46 compared to $3.54 in the 2009 fiscal year. This represents robust projected growth of 25% to 26% on top of the outstanding 52% gain we delivered in fiscal 2009.
Now, I’ll turn the call back to Michael.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. To sum up, we are very pleased with our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance. In addition, even if fourth quarter earnings perform just in line with our guidance, we will be on track to report a record operating margin of 11%
componenttext:
Thank you, John. To sum up, we are very pleased with our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance. In addition, even if fourth quarter earnings perform just in line with our guidance, we will be on track to report a record operating margin of 11% or more for fiscal 2010.
One of the most frequently asked questions we get now is, if this current level of profitability is sustainable. We strongly believe that it is due to a permanent structural change in our business model.
Over the past three years, we have made substantial gains in operating margin, driven by the successful implementation of a number of strategic initiatives. The biggest driver of our improved profitability has been record merchandise gross margin, resulting from better buying and a significant reductions we have made in selling store inventories.
Off-price buying is our most important business strategy and we remain committed to making ongoing investments in our merchandise organization. By putting hundreds of Ross and dd’s merchants in the market to source product from thousands of vendors, we are maximizing our access to the best bargains available. Going forward, we will continue to invest in this critical area of our business.
We have also been extremely successful over the last few years in operating our business on much lower inventories. Today, selling store inventories are more than 30% lower than they were just three years ago.
This sizable reduction has resulted in a much larger percentage of fresh merchandise that the customer sees while shopping our stores, which we believe had benefited sales. Lower inventories have also driven much faster inventory turns and a meaningful decline in markdown activity over this period.
Implementation of our shortage control initiatives has also benefited margins by dramatically reducing shrink over the past few years to record low levels today.
Other sustainable drivers of operating margin include the numerous productivity enhancement and efficiencies we have implemented throughout the company to drive down cost, including our distribution centers, stores organization and back office functions.
As a result of all these structural changes, we believe that annual operating margin in the low double-digit percentage range is sustainable going forward. This gives us the confidence to continue to target, over the longer-term, average annual earnings per share growth of 10% to 15%.
The formula for achieving it is a combination of unit growth, annual increases in same-store sales and ongoing reductions in diluted shares outstanding from our stock repurchase program.
In closing, we believe that consumers increased focus on price and value will continue for the foreseeable future which bodes well for our business. We also know that our ability to give our customers the best bargain possible on a wide array of fashions for the family and the home will always be the most critical factor to our success.
As a result, we will maintain an unwavering focus on what has worked so well for us over the past few years, solid execution of all our merchandising strategies along with a continued focus on tight inventory and expense controls.
At this point, we’d like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Brian Tunick from JPMorgan. Your line is now open.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Brian Tunick from JPMorgan. Your line is now open.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning, guys. I guess my question really on the uses of cash. It seems like, if you look at the balance sheet, it seems like you also would have the flexibility to either consider a special dividend that a few companies are doing today or an
componenttext:
Thanks. Good morning, guys. I guess my question really on the uses of cash. It seems like, if you look at the balance sheet, it seems like you also would have the flexibility to either consider a special dividend that a few companies are doing today or an accelerated share repurchase program.
And then as you talk about that in context for square footage growth for 2011 maybe talk about new markets with how much of the store growth next year is going to come in new markets versus existing markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Brian, this is Michael O’Sullivan. I’ll take both of them. On the usage of cash, we have a pretty good track record of increasing our dividends and buyback program to return cash to shareholders. So earlier this year, we announced 45% increase i
componenttext:
Okay, Brian, this is Michael O’Sullivan. I’ll take both of them. On the usage of cash, we have a pretty good track record of increasing our dividends and buyback program to return cash to shareholders. So earlier this year, we announced 45% increase in dividend and a 25% increase in the buyback. In the January timeframe we’ll take another look at that and make some announcements probably in early 2011 announcing further increases.
On your second question about store growth, I think we’ve announced previously that in 2011 we’ll probably have round about 6% to 7% unit growth for stores. And I would say about 1% to 2% of that would be in new markets, and hopefully that’s the product in terms of where we use cash, using cash to fuel growth.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Paul Lejuez from Nomura Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Paul Lejuez from Nomura Securities.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttext: Hi, thanks. Just maybe if I could follow-up, maybe can you talk about store growth by concept next year and maybe if you have some initial thoughts on CapEx? I guess John, I mean what’s the level of cash that you feel like you need to have on the balance sheet to feel comfortable?

componenttext: On growth by concept it was about 6% to 7%, one to two points will be dd’s and rest will be Ross approximately.
