componenttext: Regarding cash flow, as Michael said we’ll make some decisions relative to buyback and dividend as we end the year, we also have some investments to make in distribution centers to provide for the infrastructure we need. We are working on that and there’ll be more information forthcoming towards the end of the year.

componenttextpreview: Our SG&A leverage probably between say three or four comps, it’s all dependent on what we do from a top line standpoint. We tend to be pretty frugal with that sort of thing.
componenttext: Our SG&A leverage probably between say three or four comps, it’s all dependent on what we do from a top line standpoint. We tend to be pretty frugal with that sort of thing.

componenttext: Good morning, guys. componenttext: Hey, guys, congratulations and good luck for holidays. It’s nice to be on a very consistent conference call. I was curious you have increased your merchant staff quite a bit over the last several years. I feel like you are in a good place right now, but I’m from the outside, looking in, so I’m curious if you can talk a little bit about your merchant staff, both as it relates to Ross Stores and dd’s?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’ve had a strategic initiative to grow the staff for a number of years, both the buying staff in both companies as well as the planning and allocation staff and we’ve been watching with the strategy for a number of years. As I said, and we’re goin
componenttext: We’ve had a strategic initiative to grow the staff for a number of years, both the buying staff in both companies as well as the planning and allocation staff and we’ve been watching with the strategy for a number of years. As I said, and we’re going to continue to do it, it further gives us the ability to segregate businesses, get better market coverage and look for more opportunities in all the marketplaces that we trade in and we are very comfortable with the strategy. We think it’s the key initiative, it is the single key initiative that has enabled us to grow our business the way we have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. First, just wanted to talk a little bit on the SG&A side, it sounds if I understood correctly the 20 basis points of deleverage was all related to the higher incentive accrual. I am just wondering, given that you were able to achieve a 3% comp,
componenttext: Thank you. First, just wanted to talk a little bit on the SG&A side, it sounds if I understood correctly the 20 basis points of deleverage was all related to the higher incentive accrual. I am just wondering, given that you were able to achieve a 3% comp, why then would we not have seen some leverage on the SG&A line?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s correct. All of the deleverage, the 20 basis points did happen on the incentive line. We were extremely profitable during the quarter. And as we look at our business, we did achieve some leverage on occupancy and store expenses that was offset by
componenttext: That’s correct. All of the deleverage, the 20 basis points did happen on the incentive line. We were extremely profitable during the quarter. And as we look at our business, we did achieve some leverage on occupancy and store expenses that was offset by the incentives as I mentioned. We expect to deliver for the year, deleverage in SG&A, if we look at the year, and that’s probably around the 4% comps, so that’s about where it is depending on timing and other issues.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to understand, it sounds as if the comp leverage point was, as we understood it, probably a little bit lower, two to three and now it’s more three to four next year. Is that right and what has changed?
componenttext: Just to understand, it sounds as if the comp leverage point was, as we understood it, probably a little bit lower, two to three and now it’s more three to four next year. Is that right and what has changed?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The leverage point is around, like I said this year, we’ll have slight leverage around the 4; in the quarterly we didn’t lever on the 3. As we go next year, depending on how we do and from a top line stand point, we are thinking that three-ish is prob
componenttext: The leverage point is around, like I said this year, we’ll have slight leverage around the 4; in the quarterly we didn’t lever on the 3. As we go next year, depending on how we do and from a top line stand point, we are thinking that three-ish is probably the leverage point that they would probably achieve.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just shifting to the shrink performance, another great shrink performance, what sort of margin tailwind does that present over the next few quarters?
componenttext: Okay. And then just shifting to the shrink performance, another great shrink performance, what sort of margin tailwind does that present over the next few quarters?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The shrink performance from an accrual standpoint going forward, we think we’ll probably pick up 10 to 15 basis points for the fourth quarter than the first and second quarters next year as we lower that shrink accrual.
componenttext: The shrink performance from an accrual standpoint going forward, we think we’ll probably pick up 10 to 15 basis points for the fourth quarter than the first and second quarters next year as we lower that shrink accrual.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you, good morning. We are hearing about some excess supply coming available in the marketplace given some shipment deliveries and other issues and perhaps even some excess inventory this year relative to last year. I was wondering if you coul
componenttext:
Great, thank you, good morning. We are hearing about some excess supply coming available in the marketplace given some shipment deliveries and other issues and perhaps even some excess inventory this year relative to last year. I was wondering if you could offer any color on that.
And then John, on the transportation costs that are coming up, do you think that that is a temporary issue or do you think that this is sort of the new normal? Thanks.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I heard the first part of the question it was relative to excess inventory, if we’re seeing excess inventory available. Is that correct?
componenttext: If I heard the first part of the question it was relative to excess inventory, if we’re seeing excess inventory available. Is that correct?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer would be yes. It’s reflective in our packaway levels. It’s been a very good buying period and whether there’s a combination of erratic sales trend at some retailers as well as freight issues and timing of freight across from Asia. So, the
componenttext: The answer would be yes. It’s reflective in our packaway levels. It’s been a very good buying period and whether there’s a combination of erratic sales trend at some retailers as well as freight issues and timing of freight across from Asia. So, there’s been plenty of excess.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On freight; there was a lot of excess equipments and assets that were unutilized in ‘09. The carriers took that equipment out, rates came back up so all depends on what the freight equilibrium is going to be relative to equipment back in the market; ins
componenttext: On freight; there was a lot of excess equipments and assets that were unutilized in ‘09. The carriers took that equipment out, rates came back up so all depends on what the freight equilibrium is going to be relative to equipment back in the market; instinctively you think this is probably more reflective of freight as opposed to ‘09 when there was a lot destruction in the market.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing I’d say about that Kimberly is, when we came into 2010, because we benefited from low freight rates in 2009, so we build that into the budget and also it’s built into our guidance.
componenttext: The other thing I’d say about that Kimberly is, when we came into 2010, because we benefited from low freight rates in 2009, so we build that into the budget and also it’s built into our guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So this is more normal off of depressed ‘09 freight levels?
componenttext: So this is more normal off of depressed ‘09 freight levels?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, just one other follow-up question, I think you said you achieved $0.10 of improvement in the quarter because of the benefit on shortage, is that in the 85 basis points higher merchandise margin or is that separate and if you could quantify the basis
componenttext: John, just one other follow-up question, I think you said you achieved $0.10 of improvement in the quarter because of the benefit on shortage, is that in the 85 basis points higher merchandise margin or is that separate and if you could quantify the basis points benefit on shortage that would be great?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, that is in the 85 basis points of margin improvement, but having said that, we achieved 100 basis points of margin improvement in the prior year, so we’re up against 100 basis points. In the 85 basis points, we actually lost 10 basis points on the
componenttext: Sure, that is in the 85 basis points of margin improvement, but having said that, we achieved 100 basis points of margin improvement in the prior year, so we’re up against 100 basis points. In the 85 basis points, we actually lost 10 basis points on the compare, if that makes sense?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Within the 85, 75 basis points is the shortage benefit plus a 10 basis point improvement in the core merchandise margin?
componenttext: Within the 85, 75 basis points is the shortage benefit plus a 10 basis point improvement in the core merchandise margin?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, the other way around. We had 95 basis points of improvement in core merchandise margin and on a comparable basis shrink was off 10 bps because we’re up against a 100 basis point.
componenttext: No, the other way around. We had 95 basis points of improvement in core merchandise margin and on a comparable basis shrink was off 10 bps because we’re up against a 100 basis point.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other point to is just around from an EPS point-of-view, Kimberly, the benefit in Q3 was about $0.10, last year it was about $0.11, so obviously, we’ve got benefit on top of benefit. When you look at it on a margin basis, it’s a little bit confusi
componenttext: The other point to is just around from an EPS point-of-view, Kimberly, the benefit in Q3 was about $0.10, last year it was about $0.11, so obviously, we’ve got benefit on top of benefit. When you look at it on a margin basis, it’s a little bit confusing but I think it’s clear when you look at it on a dollar basis.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael.
componenttext: Thanks, Michael.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman from Wells Fargo. Your line is now open.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, good morning. I had a question on your 10% to 15% EPS growth annually. First, on the unit growth assumption in there, the low end to the high end from the 10% to 15%, what is the range of unit growth assumed in there?
componenttext: Thanks, good morning. I had a question on your 10% to 15% EPS growth annually. First, on the unit growth assumption in there, the low end to the high end from the 10% to 15%, what is the range of unit growth assumed in there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Unit growth in terms of new stores about 6% to 7% a year.
componenttext: Unit growth in terms of new stores about 6% to 7% a year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I am sorry. 6 to 7.
componenttext: I am sorry. 6 to 7.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: 6% to 7% a year, in terms of unit store.
componenttext: 6% to 7% a year, in terms of unit store.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the other question, I think this is historically, you’ve given this goal. I’m wondering if the components of how you get there have changed given your operating margins are a lot fuller. So I’m curious if the components that growth that you
componenttext: And then the other question, I think this is historically, you’ve given this goal. I’m wondering if the components of how you get there have changed given your operating margins are a lot fuller. So I’m curious if the components that growth that you would get from the margin is less now or if that hasn’t changed at all going forward?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It changed slightly, so historically I think in the past couple of years, we’ve grown the store base lower than 6% to 7%, so it was more around 4%, 5% I would assume some operating margin improvement with the repurchase I would guess between 10%, 15%. W
componenttext: It changed slightly, so historically I think in the past couple of years, we’ve grown the store base lower than 6% to 7%, so it was more around 4%, 5% I would assume some operating margin improvement with the repurchase I would guess between 10%, 15%. We’re increasing our top line 6% to 7%. We’re assuming that we’re sustaining churn operating margin levels in that long-term model, at say three comp to that and 4% earnings growth based on repurchase activities we get between 10% and 15% earnings growth per year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the unit growth of 6% to 7% per year, we were listening to the TJX conference call and I think they talked about accelerating Marmaxx openings in the U.S. and especially in Manhattan, I think taking advantage of some of real estate opportuniti
componenttext: In terms of the unit growth of 6% to 7% per year, we were listening to the TJX conference call and I think they talked about accelerating Marmaxx openings in the U.S. and especially in Manhattan, I think taking advantage of some of real estate opportunities. Do you have any thoughts on potentially accelerating your square footage growth back to the double digit rates that you used to be at and kind of what you’re seeing in the real estate market?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re going to stick to steady 6% to 7% growth, obviously we’ll be opportunistic in terms of what locations we pick up and what kind of real estate deals we do, but I think you can expect 6% to 7% for us.
componenttext: We’re going to stick to steady 6% to 7% growth, obviously we’ll be opportunistic in terms of what locations we pick up and what kind of real estate deals we do, but I think you can expect 6% to 7% for us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Which is an acceleration of where it has been most recently.
componenttext: Which is an acceleration of where it has been most recently.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice. Your line is now open.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice. Your line is now open.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. Given all the commentary out there about apparel inflation that is on its way, I am just curious Michael, if you look back in history in periods of inflation, what do you think that means for you in terms of availability of goods?
componenttext: Yes, thank you. Given all the commentary out there about apparel inflation that is on its way, I am just curious Michael, if you look back in history in periods of inflation, what do you think that means for you in terms of availability of goods?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s hard to predict, I mean what’s going on in the apparel manufacturing cycle to meet early stage, so we don’t exactly know how this is going to land, but periods of disruption in pricing create uncertainty in the whole supply line, create some un
componenttext: It’s hard to predict, I mean what’s going on in the apparel manufacturing cycle to meet early stage, so we don’t exactly know how this is going to land, but periods of disruption in pricing create uncertainty in the whole supply line, create some uncertainty and mainstream retailing and historically it’s been good for us in access of products.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the deals that you brought, the increase in packaway, should we expect to see that you might have an opportunity to use that to drive merchandise margin just given that, you are going to be selling a lot of that merchandise in a period when ot
componenttext: In terms of the deals that you brought, the increase in packaway, should we expect to see that you might have an opportunity to use that to drive merchandise margin just given that, you are going to be selling a lot of that merchandise in a period when other retailers can be raising the prices.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you should assume, it will help us in some way in sales, it wouldn’t hurt us in margin packaway it is usually high margin product for us under normal circumstances. So depending on how all this shakes out, it could be a positive but it’s reall
componenttext: I think you should assume, it will help us in some way in sales, it wouldn’t hurt us in margin packaway it is usually high margin product for us under normal circumstances. So depending on how all this shakes out, it could be a positive but it’s really as I said too early to tell that aspect of it.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you and good luck on holiday.
componenttext: Great, thank you and good luck on holiday.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray. Your line is now open.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray. Your line is now open.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. Just a couple of quick questions, on the retail square footage growth going forward, are you seeing anything in terms of changes with respect to cost and/or availability of real estate and how is that playing into your acceleration plans?
componenttext:
Yes, thank you. Just a couple of quick questions, on the retail square footage growth going forward, are you seeing anything in terms of changes with respect to cost and/or availability of real estate and how is that playing into your acceleration plans?
The second one just on this inflationary pressure cost of goods pressure in the categories both domestics and apparel, how does that play into your strategy of packaway are you taking advantages of some categories in front of the price increases or is this normal course of business?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the packaway one, first. We purchased packaway based on the quality of each unique buy and what we think the value of that product is based on the brand and the classification of merchandise. We don’t that packaway is hedge against inflation
componenttext: Let me take the packaway one, first. We purchased packaway based on the quality of each unique buy and what we think the value of that product is based on the brand and the classification of merchandise. We don’t that packaway is hedge against inflation. We think packaway we think that packaway is pure merchandise opportunities that we think our customers will value, if it turns out to be a hedge against inflation great, but that’s not our unique packaway strategy.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On your question, Jeff, real estate opportunities, certainly with everything that’s happened in the real estate market, it’s actually going to take market up couple of years. There are opportunities out there in terms of the locations and in terms of
componenttext: On your question, Jeff, real estate opportunities, certainly with everything that’s happened in the real estate market, it’s actually going to take market up couple of years. There are opportunities out there in terms of the locations and in terms of negotiating good deals and needless to say, we’re using whatever leverage we can to go after those opportunities.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So would you expect these sort of economic model of your next, 2011 cycle of new stores to be more favorable in general than your prior two cycles?
componenttext: So would you expect these sort of economic model of your next, 2011 cycle of new stores to be more favorable in general than your prior two cycles?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s hard to say, because there are so many things that go into that economic model certainly from an occupancy expense point of view the environment is more favorable now than it was a couple of years ago. The other aspects of the economic mode
componenttext: I think it’s hard to say, because there are so many things that go into that economic model certainly from an occupancy expense point of view the environment is more favorable now than it was a couple of years ago. The other aspects of the economic model obviously will play in terms of sales in total and so forth, so occupancy expense is just one piece of that. So one thing we are seeing is we are seeing a higher quality of sets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Wilson from Tiburon Research. Your line is now open.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Wilson from Tiburon Research. Your line is now open.

componenttext: It’s Stifel Nicolaus. Hi, guys. headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator In
componenttext: Good morning. Welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Balmuth.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on our call are: Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice P
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. Also on our call are: Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director of Investor Relations. We'll begin with a brief review of our third quarter performance followed by our outlook for the remainder of the year. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
Before we begin, I want to note that our comments on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results and other matters that are based on management's current forecast of aspects of the company's future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. These risk factors are detailed in today's press release and our fiscal 2009 Form 10-K, and 2010 Form 10-Qs and 8-Ks on file with the SEC. 
Today, we reported third quarter earnings of $1.02, up from $0.84 per share for the 2009 third quarter. These results represent a 21% increase on top of exceptional growth in the prior year when earnings per share were up 91%. Net earnings for the current year quarter grew 16% to a record $121.4 million, up from $105.1 million last year. 
Our third quarter sales increased 7% to $1,874,000,000, with comparable store sales up a better than expected 3% on top of an 8% gain in the prior year. For the nine months ended October 30, 2010, earnings per share were $3.26, up from $2.39 for the same period in 2009. These results represent a 36% increase on top of a robust 52% gain in earnings per share during the first nine months of last year. Year-to-date through October 30, net earnings grew 31% to a record $393 million, up from $299.9 million last year.
Sales for the first nine months of 2010 increased 10% to $5,721,000,000, with comparable store sales up 6% versus a 5% gain for the same period in 2009. We delivered strong sales and earnings increases in the third quarter and first nine months of 2010, on top of outstanding gains in the prior year. This is especially noteworthy considering the ongoing uncertainty in the macroeconomic and retail environment.
Our third quarter performance was driven by our continued ability to deliver exciting bargains while operating our business on lower inventories, as well as much better than expected shortage results. Dresses and Home were the top performing merchandise categories for the third quarter, both with low double-digit same-store sales increases. 
Geographic trends were relatively broad based. Florida remained the strongest region with low double-digit comparable store sales gains for the third quarter and first nine months. We are pleased to report that sales trends in California improved during the quarter. Despite ongoing weakness in the housing market and high unemployment, same store sales in our largest state rose 2% in the third quarter, on top of an 8% increase in the prior year. Year-to-date, California is up 3% on top of a 5% gain last year.
For the third quarter and first nine months, profit margins rose to new record levels on top of exceptional gains in the prior year. Earnings before interest and taxes as a percent of sales grew to 10.5% in the quarter for a 60 basis point increase on top of a 385 basis point gain in the same period last year. 
Gross margin rose 80 basis points as higher merchandise gross margin, lower distribution cost and leverage on occupancy expenses were partially offset mainly by higher incentive and freight costs as a percent of sales versus the prior year. Selling, general and administrative expenses grew 20 basis points, mainly due to higher incentive cost as a percent of sales. John will provide some additional details on these operating margin trends in a few minutes.
As we ended the third quarter, total consolidated inventories were up about 3% with average selling store inventory down about 10%. packaway was about 37% of total inventories compared to 32% at this time last year. We continue to plan further reductions of in-store inventories with average levels targeted down in the high single-digit percentage range in the fourth quarter compared to 2009. As we have mentioned on previous calls, our ongoing focus on tight inventory management allows us to maximize the percentage of fresh receipts the customers use while shopping our stores. It also drives faster inventory turns, fewer markdowns, and ultimately, higher merchandise gross margin.
Turning to our store expansion program. We added 12 Ross and 10 dd's DISCOUNTS stores in the most recent quarter, and ended the period with 1,057 combined locations in 27 states in Guam. 
dd's DISCOUNTS sales trends improved during the third quarter with positive comparable store sales increases on top of exceptionally strong prior year results. As I mentioned, we opened 10 dd stores in the period including entry into the Atlanta market. Year-to-date, we have added 15 locations and now operate 67 dd's DISCOUNTS stores in six states. 
Based on our year-to-date results and outlook for the fourth quarter, we continue to expect dd's DISCOUNTS to be slightly profitable in 2010 before allocations for corporate expense. Now let's talk about our financial condition.
Our balance sheet and cash flows remain healthy and we ended the quarter with $735 million of cash and short-term investments. Our cash position continues to benefit from better-than-expected earnings and reduced working capital needs as we operate the business on lower inventories. During the third quarter and first nine months of 2010, we repurchased 1.7 million and 5.4 million shares of our common stock, respectively, for an aggregate purchase price of $287 million year-to-date. We remain on track to complete, during 2010, approximately $375 million of our current two-year $750 million stock repurchase program.
I'd like to turn now to our updated outlook for the fourth quarter. As we noted in today's press release, we are solidly positioned as a value retailer, and our stores are stocked with fresh and exciting merchandise. That said, while we have outperformed our projections year-to-date, there are a number of reasons why we believe it is prudent to maintain a cautious outlook for the fourth quarter.
It still remains difficult to predict the future in today's uncertain macroeconomic and retail climate. We also see the likelihood of a very promotional and competitive holiday season this year, combined with the fact that we are up against our toughest prior year sales comparison as well as robust earnings growth. In last year's fourth quarter, same-store sales grew 10% and earnings per share rose 53%. In addition, the timing of Christmas Day means that we have one less Saturday of business in our largest volume month of the year. As a result, while we hope to do better, we are maintaining our prior forecast for both sales and earnings in the 2010 fourth quarter.
Now John will provide additional color on our third quarter results and details of our fourth quarter guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Our 3% comparable store sales gain in the third quarter was driven by a combination of low single-digit increases in both the number of transactions and in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin improved by about 60 ba
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Our 3% comparable store sales gain in the third quarter was driven by a combination of low single-digit increases in both the number of transactions and in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin improved by about 60 basis points in the quarter to 10.5%, driven by an 80 basis point increase in gross margin, partially offset by a 20 basis point rise in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales. 
Merchandise market increased about 85 basis points, mainly due to faster inventory turns that resulted in lower markdowns. As we noted with our September sales release, the shortage results from our annual physical inventory of stores were much better than expected and added about $0.10 in earnings per share to our third quarter 2010 results. 
Distribution costs declined about 50 basis points, while occupancy expense benefited the quarter by about 15 basis points. These favorable comparisons were partially offset mainly by 60 basis points in higher buying and incentive costs and a 10 basis point increase in freight expense. The 20 basis point increase in selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales is mainly due to higher incentive expenses. Our buyback program drove a 5% reduction in diluted shares outstanding, and a slightly lower tax rate added about 2% to net earnings growth in the quarter.
Turning now to our guidance for the fourth quarter. Again, for the reasons Michael just mentioned, while we hope to do better, we believe it is prudent in this environment to stay somewhat cautious as we plan our business for the holiday season. For the 13 weeks ending January 29, 2011, we continue to forecast comparable store sales to be flat to down 1% on top of our very strong 10% growth in last year's fourth quarter. Earnings per share are projected to be $1.15 to $1.20, compared to $1.16 in the prior year period when earnings per share were up a robust 53%. Our fourth quarter 2010 targets are based on the following assumptions.
Total sales are planned to grow about 3% to 4%, driven by a combination of new store growth, and as mentioned, same-store sales that are flat-to-down 1%. Our guidance assumes that comparable store sales are up 2% to 3% in November, and down 1% to 2% in both December and January. 
Last year's same-store sales rose 8%, 12%, and 8% in November, December and January, respectively. Based on these sales assumptions, operating margins for the fourth quarter is projected to be 11% to 11.2%. This compares to 11.7% in the 2009 fourth quarter. As a percent of sales, we are planning flat to slightly better merchandise gross margin that is projected to be offset by somewhat higher freight costs. 
Due to timing issues on packaway inventories, distribution costs are forecast to increase as a percent of sales in the fourth quarter. Based on our assumptions of flat to down 1% same-store sales, we would also expect to see some deleveraging on occupancy and other selling, general and administrative costs. 
Net interest expense is planned to be approximately $2 million, and our tax rate is expected to be about 38%. We also estimate weighted average diluted shares outstanding of about 118 million. Given our year-to-date performance and projections for the fourth quarter, we now are estimating earnings per share for the fiscal year ending January 29, 2011, to be in the range of $4.41 to $4.46 compared to $3.54 in the 2009 fiscal year. This represents robust projected growth of 25% to 26% on top of the outstanding 52% gain we delivered in fiscal 2009. Now I'll turn the call back to Michael.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. To sum up, we are very pleased with our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance. In addition, even if fourth quarter earnings performed just in line with our guidance, we will be on track to report a record operating margin of 1
componenttext:
Thank you, John. To sum up, we are very pleased with our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance. In addition, even if fourth quarter earnings performed just in line with our guidance, we will be on track to report a record operating margin of 11% or more for fiscal 2010. 
One of the most frequently asked questions we get now is if this current level of profitability is sustainable. We strongly believe that it is, due to a permanent structural change in our business model. Over the past three years, we have made substantial gains in operating margin, driven by the successful implementation of a number of strategic initiatives.
The biggest driver of our improved profitability has been record merchandise gross margin resulting from better buying and the significant reductions we have made in selling store inventories. Off-price buying is our most important business strategy, and we remain committed to making ongoing investments in our merchandise organization. By putting hundreds of Ross and dd's merchants in the market to source product from thousands of vendors, we are maximizing our access to the best bargains available. Going forward, we will continue to invest in this critical area of our business.
We have also been extremely successful over the last few years in operating our business on much lower inventories. Today, selling store inventories are more than 30% lower than they were just three years ago. This sizable reduction has resulted in a much larger percentage of fresh merchandise that the customer sees while shopping our stores, which we believe had benefited sales. Lower inventories have also driven much faster inventory turns and a meaningful decline in markdown activity over this period. The implementation of our shortage control initiatives has also benefited margins by dramatically reducing shrink over the past few years to record low levels today.
Other sustainable drivers of operating margin include the numerous productivity enhancements and efficiencies we have implemented throughout the company to drive down cost, including our distribution centers, stores organization and back-office functions. As a result of all these structural changes, we believe that annual operating margin in a low double-digit percentage range is sustainable going forward. 
This gives us the confidence to continue to target, over the longer term, average annual earnings per share growth of 10% to 15%. The formula for achieving this is a combination of unit growth, annual increases in same-store sales and ongoing reduction in diluted shares outstanding from our stock repurchase program.
In closing, we believe that consumers increased focus on price and value will continue for the foreseeable future, which bodes well for our business. We also know that our ability to give our customers the best bargain possible on a wide array of fashions for the family and the home will always be the most critical factor to our success. 
As a result, we will maintain an unwavering focus on what has worked so well for us over the past few years, solid execution of all our merchandising strategies, along with the continued focus on tight inventory and expense controls. At this point, we would like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttextpreview: I guess our question really on the uses of cash, it seems like if you look at the balance sheet, it seems like you also would have the flexibility to either consider a special dividend that a few companies are doing today or an accelerated share repurchas
componenttext: I guess our question really on the uses of cash, it seems like if you look at the balance sheet, it seems like you also would have the flexibility to either consider a special dividend that a few companies are doing today or an accelerated share repurchase program. And then as you talk about that in context for square footage growth for 2011, maybe talk about new markets, how much of the store growth next year is going to come in new markets versus existing markets?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Michael O'Sullivan, so I'll take both of those. On the uses of cash, we have a pretty good track record of increasing our dividend and buyback program to return cash to shareholders. So earlier this year, we announced a 45% increase in divi
componenttext: Brian, this is Michael O'Sullivan, so I'll take both of those. On the uses of cash, we have a pretty good track record of increasing our dividend and buyback program to return cash to shareholders. So earlier this year, we announced a 45% increase in dividend and a 25% increase in buyback. And in the January timeframe, we'll take another look at that and make some announcements probably in early 2011 about further increases. On your second question about store growth, I think we've announced previously that in 2011, we'll probably have around about 6% to 7% unit growth for stores. And I would say about 1% to 2% of that would be in new markets. And obviously, that's the priority in terms of where we use cash, using cash to fuel growth.

componenttext: Well, we've had a strategic initiative to grow the staff for a number of years, both the buying staff in both companies, as well as the planning and allocation staff. And we've been watching with the strategy for a number of years as I said and we're going to continue to do it. It further gives us the ability to segregate businesses, get better market coverage and look for more opportunities in all the marketplaces that we trade in. And we are very comfortable with the strategy. We think it's the key initiative. It is the single key initiative that has enabled us to grow our business the way we have.

componenttextpreview: So Marni (sic) [Adrianne], that's correct. All of the leverage of the 20 basis points did happen on the incentive line. We're extremely profitable during the quarter. And as we look at our business, we did achieve some leverage of occupancy and store expe
componenttext: So Marni (sic) [Adrianne], that's correct. All of the leverage of the 20 basis points did happen on the incentive line. We're extremely profitable during the quarter. And as we look at our business, we did achieve some leverage of occupancy and store expenses that was offset by the incentives, as I mentioned. We expect to deliver for the year, deleverage in SG&A. If we look at the year, that's probably around the four comps. So that's about where it is, depending on timing and other issues.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just so I understand, it sounds as if you had the comp leverage point was, as we understood it, probably a little bit lower, two to three, and now it's more three to four next year. Is that right? And what has changed?
componenttext: Just so I understand, it sounds as if you had the comp leverage point was, as we understood it, probably a little bit lower, two to three, and now it's more three to four next year. Is that right? And what has changed?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The leverage point is around, like I said this year, we'll have some slight leverage around the four in the quarter. We did lever on the three. As you go next year, depending on how we do and from a topline standpoint, we're thinking that 3-ish is probabl
componenttext: The leverage point is around, like I said this year, we'll have some slight leverage around the four in the quarter. We did lever on the three. As you go next year, depending on how we do and from a topline standpoint, we're thinking that 3-ish is probably the leverage point that they would probably achieve.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just shifting to the shrink performance, another great shrink performance. What sort of margin tailwind does that present over the next two quarters?
componenttext: And then just shifting to the shrink performance, another great shrink performance. What sort of margin tailwind does that present over the next two quarters?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The shrink performance from an accrual standpoint going forward, we think we'll probably pick up 10 to 15 basis points for the fourth quarter than the first and second quarters next year, as we lower that shrink accrual.
componenttext: The shrink performance from an accrual standpoint going forward, we think we'll probably pick up 10 to 15 basis points for the fourth quarter than the first and second quarters next year, as we lower that shrink accrual.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger for Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger for Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are hearing about some excess supply coming available in the marketplace given some shipment deliveries and other issues, and perhaps, given some excess inventory this year relative to last year. I was wondering if you could offer any color on that. An
componenttext: We are hearing about some excess supply coming available in the marketplace given some shipment deliveries and other issues, and perhaps, given some excess inventory this year relative to last year. I was wondering if you could offer any color on that. And then, John, on the transportation costs that are coming up, do you think that, that is a temporary issue or do you think that this is sort of the new normal?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I heard the first part of the question, it was relative to excess inventory, if we're seeing excess inventory available? Is that correct?
componenttext: If I heard the first part of the question, it was relative to excess inventory, if we're seeing excess inventory available? Is that correct?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer would be yes. It's reflected in our packaway levels. It's been a very good buying period. And whether that's been a combination of erratic sales trend at some retailers, as well as freight issues and timing of freight across from Asia. So there
componenttext: The answer would be yes. It's reflected in our packaway levels. It's been a very good buying period. And whether that's been a combination of erratic sales trend at some retailers, as well as freight issues and timing of freight across from Asia. So there's been plenty of excess.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on freight, so there was a lot of excess equipment and assets that were underutilized in '09. The carriers took that equipment out. Rates came back up. So it all depends on what the freight load [ph] is going to be relative to the equipment back in th
componenttext: And on freight, so there was a lot of excess equipment and assets that were underutilized in '09. The carriers took that equipment out. Rates came back up. So it all depends on what the freight load [ph] is going to be relative to the equipment back in the market. Instinctively, I think this is probably more reflective of freight as opposed to '09 when there was a lot of obstruction in the market.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing I'd say about that, Kimberly, is, when we came into 2010, we have to do -- the freight rates would normalize because we benefited from low freight rates in 2009. So we built that into our budget, and obviously, built into our guidance.
componenttext: The other thing I'd say about that, Kimberly, is, when we came into 2010, we have to do -- the freight rates would normalize because we benefited from low freight rates in 2009. So we built that into our budget, and obviously, built into our guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So this is more normal, off of the question on freight levels. And John, just one other follow-up question. I think you said you achieved $0.10 of improvement in the quarter because of the benefit on shortage. Is that in the 85 basis points higher merchan
componenttext: So this is more normal, off of the question on freight levels. And John, just one other follow-up question. I think you said you achieved $0.10 of improvement in the quarter because of the benefit on shortage. Is that in the 85 basis points higher merchandise margin or is that separate? And if you could quantify the basis points benefit on shortage, that would be great.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. That is in the 85 basis points of margin improvement. Having said that, we achieved 100 basis points of margin improvement in the prior year. So we're up against 100 basis points. In the 85 basis points, we actually lapped 10 basis points on the com
componenttext: Sure. That is in the 85 basis points of margin improvement. Having said that, we achieved 100 basis points of margin improvement in the prior year. So we're up against 100 basis points. In the 85 basis points, we actually lapped 10 basis points on the compare.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Within the 85, 75 basis points is the shortage benefit, plus the 10 basis point improvement in the core merchandise margin?
componenttext: Within the 85, 75 basis points is the shortage benefit, plus the 10 basis point improvement in the core merchandise margin?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, the other way around. We had 95 basis points of improvement in kind of core merchandise margin. And on a comparable basis, shrink was up 10 bps because we were up against 100 basis points.
componenttext: No, the other way around. We had 95 basis points of improvement in kind of core merchandise margin. And on a comparable basis, shrink was up 10 bps because we were up against 100 basis points.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other point to make is just from an EPS point of view, Kimberly, the benefit in Q3 was about $0.10. Last year, it was about $0.11. So obviously, we got benefit on top of benefit. When you look at it on a margin basis, it's a little bit confusing. But
componenttext: The other point to make is just from an EPS point of view, Kimberly, the benefit in Q3 was about $0.10. Last year, it was about $0.11. So obviously, we got benefit on top of benefit. When you look at it on a margin basis, it's a little bit confusing. But I think it's clear when you look at it on a dollar basis.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Evren Kopelman from Wells Fargo.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a question on your 10% to 15% EPS growth kind of annually. First, on the unit growth assumption in there, the lowest, the high-end, from the 10% to 15%, what is the range of unit growth assumed in there?
componenttext: I had a question on your 10% to 15% EPS growth kind of annually. First, on the unit growth assumption in there, the lowest, the high-end, from the 10% to 15%, what is the range of unit growth assumed in there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our unit growth in terms of new stores is 6% to 7% per year.
componenttext: Our unit growth in terms of new stores is 6% to 7% per year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, 6% to 7%?
componenttext: I'm sorry, 6% to 7%?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: 6% to 7% per year.
componenttext: 6% to 7% per year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the other question, though I think this is historically given this goal, I'm wondering if the components of how you get there have changed given your operating margins are a lot fuller. So I'm curious if the components that growth that you would
componenttext: And then the other question, though I think this is historically given this goal, I'm wondering if the components of how you get there have changed given your operating margins are a lot fuller. So I'm curious if the components that growth that you would get from the margin is less now or if that hasn't changed at all going forward?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It changed slightly. So historically, the past couple of years, we've grown the store base lower than 6% to 7%. So it' more around 4% to 5%. And we'd assume some operating margin improvement with the repurchase. So it gets us between 10% and 15%. We're in
componenttext: It changed slightly. So historically, the past couple of years, we've grown the store base lower than 6% to 7%. So it' more around 4% to 5%. And we'd assume some operating margin improvement with the repurchase. So it gets us between 10% and 15%. We're increasing our top line of 6% to 7%, we are assuming that we're sustaining churn operating margin levels in that long-term model. Add a, say, three comp to that and 4% earnings growth based on repurchase activities, we get between the 10% and 15% earnings growth per year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of unit growth, the 6% to 7% per year, we were listening to the TJX conference call and I think they talked about accelerating Marmaxx openings in the U.S., especially in Manhattan, I think taking advantage of some of the real estate opp
componenttext: And then in terms of unit growth, the 6% to 7% per year, we were listening to the TJX conference call and I think they talked about accelerating Marmaxx openings in the U.S., especially in Manhattan, I think taking advantage of some of the real estate opportunities. Do you have any thoughts on potentially accelerating your square footage growth back to the double-digit rates that used to be at? Kind of what you're seeing in the real estate market.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. We're going to stick to the 6% to 7% growth. Obviously, we'll be opportunistic in terms of what locations we pick up and what kind of real estate deals we do. But I think you can expect 6% to 7% as far as going to be.
componenttext: No. We're going to stick to the 6% to 7% growth. Obviously, we'll be opportunistic in terms of what locations we pick up and what kind of real estate deals we do. But I think you can expect 6% to 7% as far as going to be.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Which was an acceleration of where it has been most recently.
componenttext: Which was an acceleration of where it has been most recently.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given all the commentary out there about apparel inflation that is on its way. I'm just curious, Michael, when you look back in history, in periods of inflation, what do you think that means for you in terms of availability of goods?
componenttext: Given all the commentary out there about apparel inflation that is on its way. I'm just curious, Michael, when you look back in history, in periods of inflation, what do you think that means for you in terms of availability of goods?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's kind of hard to predict. I mean, what's going on in the apparel manufacturing cycle is in the early stage. So we don't exactly know how this is going to land. But periods of disruption in pricing create uncertainty in the whole supply line, create so
componenttext: It's kind of hard to predict. I mean, what's going on in the apparel manufacturing cycle is in the early stage. So we don't exactly know how this is going to land. But periods of disruption in pricing create uncertainty in the whole supply line, create some uncertainty at mainstream retailing, and historically, has been good for us in access of products.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the deals that you bought, the increase in packaway, should we expect to see that you might have an opportunity to use that to drive merchandise margin just given that you're going to be selling a lot of that merchandise in a period w
componenttext: And then in terms of the deals that you bought, the increase in packaway, should we expect to see that you might have an opportunity to use that to drive merchandise margin just given that you're going to be selling a lot of that merchandise in a period when other retailers can be raising their prices?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you should assume it will help us in some way in sales. It wouldn't hurt us and margin packaway is usually a high-margin product for us under normal circumstances. So depending on how this all shakes out, it could be a positive, but it's really, a
componenttext: I think you should assume it will help us in some way in sales. It wouldn't hurt us and margin packaway is usually a high-margin product for us under normal circumstances. So depending on how this all shakes out, it could be a positive, but it's really, as I said, too early to tell that aspect though.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the retail square footage growth going forward, are you seeing anything in terms of changes with respect to cost and/or availability of real estate? And how is that kind of playing into your acceleration plans? And the second one, just be on this infla
componenttext: On the retail square footage growth going forward, are you seeing anything in terms of changes with respect to cost and/or availability of real estate? And how is that kind of playing into your acceleration plans? And the second one, just be on this inflationary pressure, cost of goods pressure in the categories, both domestics and apparel, how does that play into your strategy of packaway? Are you taking advantage of some categories in front of the price increases or is this normal course of business?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the packaway one first. We purchased packaway based on the quality of each unique product. And what we think the value of that product is based on the brand and the classification of merchandise. We don't think of packaway as a hedge against i
componenttext: Let me take the packaway one first. We purchased packaway based on the quality of each unique product. And what we think the value of that product is based on the brand and the classification of merchandise. We don't think of packaway as a hedge against inflation. We think of packaway as pure merchandise opportunities that we think our customers will value. If it turns out to be a hedge against inflation, great. But that's not our unique packaway strategy.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on your question, Jeff, about real estate opportunities, certainly, we don't think that's happened in the real estate market, the real estate market the last couple of years. There are opportunities out there in terms of locations and in terms of
componenttext: And then on your question, Jeff, about real estate opportunities, certainly, we don't think that's happened in the real estate market, the real estate market the last couple of years. There are opportunities out there in terms of locations and in terms of negotiating good deals. And needless to say, we're using more leverage as we can to go after those opportunities.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So would you expect this sort of economic model of your 2011 cycle of new stores to be more favorable in general than your prior two cycles?
componenttext: So would you expect this sort of economic model of your 2011 cycle of new stores to be more favorable in general than your prior two cycles?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's hard to say. There are so many things that go into that economic model. Certainly, from an occupancy expense point of view, the environment is more favorable now than it was a couple of years ago. But the other aspects of the economic model o
componenttext: I think it's hard to say. There are so many things that go into that economic model. Certainly, from an occupancy expense point of view, the environment is more favorable now than it was a couple of years ago. But the other aspects of the economic model obviously will play in terms of sales and so forth. [indiscernible].

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: One thing we are seeing is we're seeing a higher quality of sets.
componenttext: One thing we are seeing is we're seeing a higher quality of sets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Wilson from Tiburon Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Wilson from Tiburon Research.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, you mentioned that dd's would be slightly profitable this year before the allocation of a corporate overhead. Could you remind us maybe what that compares to last year?
componenttext: John, you mentioned that dd's would be slightly profitable this year before the allocation of a corporate overhead. Could you remind us maybe what that compares to last year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So compared to last year, it was slightly unprofitable.
componenttext: So compared to last year, it was slightly unprofitable.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Shrink, you've obviously had a lot of success over the last few years reducing shrink. Can you give us some range of what shrink may have been as a percent of sales or some order of magnitude maybe three years ago versus what it is today?.
componenttext: Shrink, you've obviously had a lot of success over the last few years reducing shrink. Can you give us some range of what shrink may have been as a percent of sales or some order of magnitude maybe three years ago versus what it is today?.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, what I always say is that shrink has come down substantially versus where it was three years ago. We don't disclose the number or the percentage of sales. But it's come down substantially. So we're very happy with that performance.
componenttext: I think, what I always say is that shrink has come down substantially versus where it was three years ago. We don't disclose the number or the percentage of sales. But it's come down substantially. So we're very happy with that performance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your last question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your last question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the inventory, as inventory turns more quickly and you've got a bigger team out in the field, is the focus on packaway diminishing and the idea being buying closer to need and buying with more market intelligence as it were? Or is the
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the inventory, as inventory turns more quickly and you've got a bigger team out in the field, is the focus on packaway diminishing and the idea being buying closer to need and buying with more market intelligence as it were? Or is the strategy still the balance between packaway and in-store merchandise?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The strategy is to be flexible. So when packaway opportunities are plentiful, we raise it as we are now. And when there are less of lesser quality, we shrink the level. And that's what drives its penetration for our total inventory level.
componenttext: The strategy is to be flexible. So when packaway opportunities are plentiful, we raise it as we are now. And when there are less of lesser quality, we shrink the level. And that's what drives its penetration for our total inventory level.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the level we're seeing now is sort of around the average?
componenttext: And the level we're seeing now is sort of around the average?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's higher than it's been recently, and it's been a function of some very strong buying opportunities on some very, very good products. And we're very happy to have it in our packaway facility.
componenttext: It's higher than it's been recently, and it's been a function of some very strong buying opportunities on some very, very good products. And we're very happy to have it in our packaway facility.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it'll remain an important part of the strategy in that 30% to 40% range of your inventory?
componenttext: So it'll remain an important part of the strategy in that 30% to 40% range of your inventory?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would expect that to be, and it's creeping up in the upper 30s today. And so if packaway opportunities continue to be very strong as we move through this fourth quarter, it could creep up another few points.
componenttext: I would expect that to be, and it's creeping up in the upper 30s today. And so if packaway opportunities continue to be very strong as we move through this fourth quarter, it could creep up another few points.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And given the success of the shrink or the reduction of shrink, if you were to say that the industry average for all apparel retailers is about 2%, would it be safe to say that at one point you were above average and now you're below average?
componenttext: And given the success of the shrink or the reduction of shrink, if you were to say that the industry average for all apparel retailers is about 2%, would it be safe to say that at one point you were above average and now you're below average?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, honestly, I would caution you not to sort of compare with industry metrics. When we're trying to do that, and frankly, everyone registering in a different way. So it's really not a meaningful comparison. I think what we have been saying is what we sai
componenttext: No, honestly, I would caution you not to sort of compare with industry metrics. When we're trying to do that, and frankly, everyone registering in a different way. So it's really not a meaningful comparison. I think what we have been saying is what we said a few moments ago, which is we weren’t happy with shrink three or four years ago. And we’ve made a lot of improvements and we're very happy with the success we've seen.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the level today is a go forward sort of a stable or sustainable level?
componenttext: And the level today is a go forward sort of a stable or sustainable level?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we believe it is.
componenttext: Yes, we believe it is.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And at this time, we have no further questions. I'll turn the call back over to you.
componenttext: And at this time, we have no further questions. I'll turn the call back over to you.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us today and best wishes to all of you for the holiday season.
componenttext: Thank you for joining us today and best wishes to all of you for the holiday season.
